Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: This paper presents the winning system for the propaganda Technique Classification (TC) task and the second-placed system for the propaganda Span Identification (SI) task. The purpose of TC task was to identify an applied propaganda technique given propaganda text fragment. The goal of SI task was to find specific text fragments which contain at least one propaganda technique. Both of the developed solutions used semi-supervised le
output_text: En el artículo titulado "ApplicaAI at SemEval-2020 Task 11: On RoBERTa-CRF, Span CLS and Whether Self-Training Helps Them" escrito por Jurkiewicz, Dawid et al., los sistemas propuestos se basan en el modelo de lenguaje RoBERTa (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers).

title: Considerations for meaningful sign language machine translation based on glosses
abstract: Automatic sign language processing is gaining popularity in Natural Language Processing (NLP) research (Yin et al., 2021). In machine translation (MT) in particular, sign language translation based on glosses is a prominent approach. In this paper, we review recent works on neural gloss translation. We find that limitations of glosses in general and limitations of specific datasets are not discussed in a transparent manner and that there is no common standard for evaluation. To address these issues, we put forward concrete recommendations for future research on gloss translation. Our suggestions advocate awareness of the inherent limitations of gloss-based approaches, realistic datasets, stronger baselines and convincing evaluation.
question: ¿Qué tipo de información contiene la base de datos PHOENIX?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Considerations for meaningful sign language machine translation based on glosses" escrito por Müller,Mathias  et al., ¿qué tipo de información contiene la base de datos PHOENIX? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Automatic sign language processing is gaining popularity in Natural Language Processing (NLP) research (Yin et al., 2021). In machine translation (MT) in particular, sign language translation based on glosses is a prominent approach. In this paper, we review recent works on neural gloss translation. We find that limitations of glosses in general and limitations of specific datasets are not discussed in a transparent manner and that
output_text: La base de datos PHOENIX contiene información sobre el lenguaje de señas americano (ASL) y el lenguaje de señas británico (BSL). Esta base de datos es una colección de vídeos que muestran a individuos realizando varias frases y oraciones en sus respectivos lenguajes de señas. Estos vídeos son utilizados como base para desarrollar algoritmos y modelos de traducción de lenguaje de señas. La base de datos PHOENIX es un recurso valioso para investigadores y desarrolladores que trabajan en el campo de la traducción automática de lenguaje de señas.

title: Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
abstract: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches generally fall short when tracking unknown slot values during inference and often have difficulties in adapting to new domains. In this paper, we propose a Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE) that generates dialogue states from utterances using copy mechanism, facilitating transfer when predicting (domain, slot, value) triplets not encountered during training. Our model is composed of an utterance encoder, a slot gate, and a state generator, which are shared across domains. Empirical results demonstrate that TRADE achieves state-of-the-art 48.62% joint goal accuracy for the five domains of MultiWOZ, a human-human dialogue dataset. In addition, we show the transferring ability by simulating zero-shot and few-shot dialogue state tracking for unseen domains. TRADE achieves 60.58% joint goal accuracy in one of the zero-shot domains, and is able to adapt to few-shot cases without forgetting already trained domains.
question: ¿Cuáles son los tres componentes del modelo propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" escrito por Wu,Chien-Sheng  et al., ¿cuáles son los tres componentes del modelo propuesto? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches generally fall short when tracking unknown slot values during inference and often have difficulties in adapting to new domains. In this paper, we propose a Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE) that generates dialogue states from utterances using copy
output_text: En el artículo "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" de Wu, Chien-Sheng et al., el modelo propuesto consta de tres componentes principales:1. Transferable Dialogue State Encoder (TRADE): Este componente es responsable de generar estados de diálogo a partir de las frases utilizando la técnica de copia. Aprende a codificar la información relevante del contexto del diálogo y el contenido de la frase en un espacio de representación de menor dimensión.2. Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator: Este componente utiliza la información codificada por el TRADE para generar estados de diálogo para diferentes dominios. Aprende a generar estados de diálogo que sean relevantes para el contexto del diálogo y el contenido de la frase, independientemente del dominio específico.3. Transfer Learning Mechanism: Este componente permite al modelo adaptarse a nuevos dominios y mejorar su rendimiento a través del aprendizaje por transferencia. Aprende a transferir el conocimiento adquirido de dominios anteriores a nuevos dominios, permitiendo al modelo generar estados de diálogo más precisos y relevantes.

title: UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation
abstract: The vast majority of evaluation metrics for machine translation are supervised, i.e., (i) are trained on human scores, (ii) assume the existence of reference translations, or (iii) leverage parallel data. This hinders their applicability to cases where such supervision signals are not available. In this work, we develop fully unsupervised evaluation metrics. To do so, we leverage similarities and synergies between evaluation metric induction, parallel corpus mining, and MT systems. In particular, we use an unsupervised evaluation metric to mine pseudo-parallel data, which we use to remap deficient underlying vector spaces (in an iterative manner) and to induce an unsupervised MT system, which then provides pseudo-references as an additional component in the metric. Finally, we also induce unsupervised multilingual sentence embeddings from pseudo-parallel data. We show that our fully unsupervised metrics are effective, i.e., they beat supervised competitors on 4 out of our 5 evaluation datasets. We make our code publicly available.
question: ¿Cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" escrito por Belouadi,Jonas  et al., ¿cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: The vast majority of evaluation metrics for machine translation are supervised, i.e., (i) are trained on human scores, (ii) assume the existence of reference translations, or (iii) leverage parallel data. This hinders their applicability to cases where such supervision signals are not available. In this work, we develop fully unsupervised evaluation metrics. To do so, we leverage similarities and synergies between evaluation metric
output_text: En el artículo "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" de Belouadi, Jonas, et al., las métricas de evaluación se clasifican según los tipos de supervisión de la siguiente manera:1. Métricas supervisadas: La mayoría de las métricas de evaluación para la traducción automática son supervisadas, lo que significa que (i) están entrenadas en puntuaciones humanas, (ii) asumen la existencia de traducciones de referencia o (iii) utilizan datos paralelos. Estas métricas están limitadas en su aplicabilidad cuando no están disponibles señales de supervisión.2. Métricas no supervisadas: El trabajo propuesto desarrolla métricas de evaluación completamente no supervisadas, que no dependen de señales de supervisión. Estas métricas tienen como objetivo superar las limitaciones de las métricas supervisadas y proporcionar una evaluación más precisa en casos donde no están disponibles señales de supervisión.

title: Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting
abstract: The growing capabilities of AI models are leading to their wider use, including in safety-critical domains. Explainable AI (XAI) aims to make these models safer to use by making their inference process more transparent. However, current explainability methods are seldom evaluated in the way they are intended to be used: by real-world end users. To address this, we conducted a large-scale user study with 85 healthcare practitioners in the context of human-AI collaborative chest X-ray analysis. We evaluated three types of explanations: visual explanations (saliency maps), natural language explanations, and a combination of both modalities. We specifically examined how different explanation types influence users depending on whether the AI advice and explanations are factually correct. We find that text-based explanations lead to significant over-reliance, which is alleviated by combining them with saliency maps. We also observe that the quality of explanations, that is, how much factually correct information they entail, and how much this aligns with AI correctness, significantly impacts the usefulness of the different explanation types.
question: ¿Qué competencias y conocimientos tenían los participantes reclutados para el estudio?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting" escrito por Kayser,Maxime Guillaume  et al., ¿qué competencias y conocimientos tenían los participantes reclutados para el estudio? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: The growing capabilities of AI models are leading to their wider use, including in safety-critical domains. Explainable AI (XAI) aims to make these models safer to use by making their inference process more transparent. However, current explainability methods are seldom evaluated in the way they are intended to be used: by real-world end users. To address this, we conducted a large-scale user study with 85 healthcare practitioners
output_text: En el estudio "Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting" de Kayser, Maxime Guillaume, y otros, los participantes reclutados fueron 85 profesionales de la atención sanitaria. Los participantes tenían conocimientos y competencias en el campo de la atención sanitaria, ya que eran profesionales que trabajaban en el sector de la atención sanitaria. El estudio tenía como objetivo evaluar la efectividad de los métodos de explicabilidad en la toma de decisiones clínicas, utilizando modelos de IA en un entorno de apoyo a la decisión clínica.

title: Multi-party Multimodal Conversations Between Patients, Their Companions, and a Social Robot in a Hospital Memory Clinic
abstract: We have deployed an LLM-based spoken dialogue system in a real hospital. The ARI social robot embodies our system, which patients and their companions can have multi-party conversations with together. In order to enable this multi-party ability, multimodality is critical. Our system, therefore, receives speech and video as input, and generates both speech and gestures (arm, head, and eye movements). In this paper, we describe our complex setting and the architecture of our dialogue system. Each component is detailed, and a video of the full system is available with the appropriate components highlighted in real-time. Our system decides when it should take its turn, generates human-like clarification requests when the patient pauses mid-utterance, answers in-domain questions (grounding to the in-prompt knowledge), and responds appropriately to out-of-domain requests (like generating jokes or quizzes). This latter feature is particularly remarkable as real patients often utter unexpected sentences that could not be handled previously.
question: ¿Qué tipo de datos genera el modelo propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Multi-party Multimodal Conversations Between Patients, Their Companions, and a Social Robot in a Hospital Memory Clinic" escrito por Addlesee,Angus  et al., ¿qué tipo de datos genera el modelo propuesto? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: We have deployed an LLM-based spoken dialogue system in a real hospital. The ARI social robot embodies our system, which patients and their companions can have multi-party conversations with together. In order to enable this multi-party ability, multimodality is critical. Our system, therefore, receives speech and video as input, and generates both speech and gestures (arm, head, and eye movements). In this paper, we describe our c
output_text: El modelo propuesto genera datos de conversaciones multimodales entre pacientes, sus acompañantes y un robot social. Estos datos incluyen entrada de habla y video, así como salida de habla y gestos (movimientos de brazo, cabeza y ojos).

title: Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck
abstract: Pre-trained word embeddings like ELMo and BERT contain rich syntactic and semantic information, resulting in state-of-the-art performance on various tasks. We propose a very fast variational information bottleneck (VIB) method to nonlinearly compress these embeddings, keeping only the information that helps a discriminative parser. We compress each word embedding to either a discrete tag or a continuous vector. In the discrete version, our automatically compressed tags form an alternative tag set: we show experimentally that our tags capture most of the information in traditional POS tag annotations, but our tag sequences can be parsed more accurately at the same level of tag granularity. In the continuous version, we show experimentally that moderately compressing the word embeddings by our method yields a more accurate parser in 8 of 9 languages, unlike simple dimensionality reduction.
question: ¿Qué modelo pre-entrenado se usó para los datos en inglés?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck" escrito por Li,Xiang Lisa  et al., ¿qué modelo pre-entrenado se usó para los datos en inglés? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Pre-trained word embeddings like ELMo and BERT contain rich syntactic and semantic information, resulting in state-of-the-art performance on various tasks. We propose a very fast variational information bottleneck (VIB) method to nonlinearly compress these embeddings, keeping only the information that helps a discriminative parser. We compress each word embedding to either a discrete tag or a continuous vector. In the discrete vers
output_text: El artículo "Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck" de Li, Xiang Lisa, et al. utiliza el modelo pre-entrenado ELMo para los datos en inglés. ELMo (Embedding de Longitud de Máquina) es un modelo de incrustación de palabras que tiene en cuenta el contexto de la palabra, lo que lo hace particularmente adecuado para tareas como el análisis de texto y el procesamiento de lenguaje natural.

title: Don’t Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments
abstract: A key missing capacity of current language models (LMs) is grounding to real-world environments. Most existing work for grounded language understanding uses LMs to directly generate plans that can be executed in the environment to achieve the desired effects. It thereby casts the burden of ensuring grammaticality, faithfulness, and controllability all on the LMs. We propose Pangu, a generic framework for grounded language understanding that capitalizes on the discriminative ability of LMs instead of their generative ability. Pangu consists of a symbolic agent and a neural LM working in a concerted fashion: The agent explores the environment to incrementally construct valid plans, and the LM evaluates the plausibility of the candidate plans to guide the search process. A case study on the challenging problem of knowledge base question answering (KBQA), which features a massive environment, demonstrates the remarkable effectiveness and flexibility of Pangu: A BERT-base LM is sufficient for setting a new record on standard KBQA datasets, and larger LMs further bring substantial gains.Pangu also enables, for the first time, effective few-shot in-context learning for KBQA with large LMs such as Codex.
question: ¿Cuáles son los dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje que discuten los autores?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Don’t Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments" escrito por Gu,Yu  et al., ¿cuáles son los dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje que discuten los autores? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: A key missing capacity of current language models (LMs) is grounding to real-world environments. Most existing work for grounded language understanding uses LMs to directly generate plans that can be executed in the environment to achieve the desired effects. It thereby casts the burden of ensuring grammaticality, faithfulness, and controllability all on the LMs. We propose Pangu, a generic framework for grounded language understan
output_text: En el artículo "Don't Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments" de Gu, Yu et al., los autores discuten dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje: generación y discriminación. El enfoque tradicional de usar modelos de lenguaje (LMs) para la comprensión del lenguaje basada en el mundo implica generar planes que pueden ser ejecutados en el entorno para lograr los efectos deseados. Sin embargo, este enfoque coloca la responsabilidad de asegurar la corrección gramatical, la fiabilidad y la controlabilidad en los LMs. Los autores proponen Pangu, un marco genérico para la comprensión del lenguaje basada en el mundo que utiliza procesos de aprendizaje de discriminación en lugar de generación para abordar estas limitaciones.

title: Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training
abstract: Methods to generate text from structured data have advanced significantly in recent years, primarily due to fine-tuning of pre-trained language models on large datasets. However, such models can fail to produce output faithful to the input data, particularly on out-of-domain data. Sufficient annotated data is often not available for specific domains, leading us to seek an unsupervised approach to improve the faithfulness of output text. Since the problem is fundamentally one of consistency between the representations of the structured data and text, we evaluate the effectiveness of cycle training in this work. Cycle training uses two models which are inverses of each other: one that generates text from structured data, and one which generates the structured data from natural language text. We show that cycle training, when initialized with a small amount of supervised data (100 samples in our case), achieves nearly the same performance as fully supervised approaches for the data-to-text generation task on the WebNLG, E2E, WTQ, and WSQL datasets. We perform extensive empirical analysis with automated evaluation metrics and a newly designed human evaluation schema to reveal different cycle training strategies’ effectiveness of reducing various types of generation errors. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/Edillower/CycleNLG.
question: ¿Qué conjuntos de datos se usaron para los experimentos?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training" escrito por Wang,Zhuoer  et al., ¿qué conjuntos de datos se usaron para los experimentos? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Methods to generate text from structured data have advanced significantly in recent years, primarily due to fine-tuning of pre-trained language models on large datasets. However, such models can fail to produce output faithful to the input data, particularly on out-of-domain data. Sufficient annotated data is often not available for specific domains, leading us to seek an unsupervised approach to improve the faithfulness of output
output_text: El artículo "Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training" de Wang, Zhuoer et al. utiliza el conjunto de datos de Wikipedia como el conjunto de datos principal para los experimentos. El conjunto de datos de Wikipedia es un conjunto de datos grande y diverso que cubre una amplia gama de temas, lo que lo convierte en un conjunto de datos adecuado para evaluar el rendimiento de los modelos de generación de texto. Además, el artículo también utiliza el conjunto de datos de New York Times (NYT) para la evaluación, que es un conjunto de datos más pequeño en comparación con el conjunto de datos de Wikipedia. El conjunto de datos de NYT se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en un conjunto de datos más pequeño y específico.

title: Pretraining Data Detection for Large Language Models: A Divergence-based Calibration Method
abstract: As the scale of training corpora for large language models (LLMs) grows, model developers become increasingly reluctant to disclose details on their data. This lack of transparency poses challenges to scientific evaluation and ethical deployment. Recently, pretraining data detection approaches, which infer whether a given text was part of an LLM’s training data through black-box access, have been explored. The Min-K% Prob method, which has achieved state-of-the-art results, assumes that a non-training example tends to contain a few outlier words with low token probabilities. However, the effectiveness may be limited as it tends to misclassify non-training texts that contain many common words with high probabilities predicted by LLMs. To address this issue, we introduce a divergence-based calibration method, inspired by the divergence-from-randomness concept, to calibrate token probabilities for pretraining data detection. We compute the cross-entropy (i.e., the divergence) between the token probability distribution and the token frequency distribution to derive a detection score.We have developed a Chinese-language benchmark, PatentMIA, to assess the performance of detection approaches for LLMs on Chinese text. Experimental results on English-language benchmarks and PatentMIA demonstrate that our proposed method significantly outperforms existing methods. Our code and PatentMIA benchmark are available at https://github.com/zhang-wei-chao/DC-PDD.
question: ¿Cuáles son las tres variantes del método que se usó para los estudios de ablación?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Pretraining Data Detection for Large Language Models: A Divergence-based Calibration Method" escrito por Zhang,Weichao  et al., ¿cuáles son las tres variantes del método que se usó para los estudios de ablación? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: As the scale of training corpora for large language models (LLMs) grows, model developers become increasingly reluctant to disclose details on their data. This lack of transparency poses challenges to scientific evaluation and ethical deployment. Recently, pretraining data detection approaches, which infer whether a given text was part of an LLM’s training data through black-box access, have been explored. The Min-K% Prob method, w
output_text: En el artículo "Pretraining Data Detection for Large Language Models: A Divergence-based Calibration Method" de Zhang, Weichao et al., se utilizaron tres variantes del método para estudios de ablación. Estas variantes son:1. Método de probabilidad mínima (Min-K%): Este método selecciona el valor mínimo de probabilidad de salida de la LLM para cada palabra en el texto de entrada y calcula la probabilidad media. Si esta probabilidad media está por debajo de un umbral específico (K%), se considera que el texto es probable que sea parte de los datos de preentrenamiento.2. Método de probabilidad media (Avg-K%): Este método calcula la probabilidad media de salida de la LLM para cada palabra en el texto de entrada. Si esta probabilidad media está por debajo de un umbral específico (K%), se considera que el texto es probable que sea parte de los datos de preentrenamiento.3. Método de probabilidad mínima ponderada (Min-K%_w): Este método es una combinación del Método de probabilidad mínima y el Método de probabilidad media. Calcula la probabilidad media ponderada de salida de la LLM para cada palabra en el texto de entrada, donde las probabilidades se ponderan por la frecuencia de la palabra en el vocabulario. Si esta probabilidad media ponderada está por debajo de un umbral específico (K%), se considera que el texto es probable que sea parte de los datos de preentrenamiento.

title: Including Signed Languages in Natural Language Processing
abstract: Signed languages are the primary means of communication for many deaf and hard of hearing individuals. Since signed languages exhibit all the fundamental linguistic properties of natural language, we believe that tools and theories of Natural Language Processing (NLP) are crucial towards its modeling. However, existing research in Sign Language Processing (SLP) seldom attempt to explore and leverage the linguistic organization of signed languages. This position paper calls on the NLP community to include signed languages as a research area with high social and scientific impact. We first discuss the linguistic properties of signed languages to consider during their modeling. Then, we review the limitations of current SLP models and identify the open challenges to extend NLP to signed languages. Finally, we urge (1) the adoption of an efficient tokenization method; (2) the development of linguistically-informed models; (3) the collection of real-world signed language data; (4) the inclusion of local signed language communities as an active and leading voice in the direction of research.
question: ¿A qué se refiere la fonología?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Including Signed Languages in Natural Language Processing" escrito por Yin,Kayo  et al., ¿a qué se refiere la fonología? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Signed languages are the primary means of communication for many deaf and hard of hearing individuals. Since signed languages exhibit all the fundamental linguistic properties of natural language, we believe that tools and theories of Natural Language Processing (NLP) are crucial towards its modeling. However, existing research in Sign Language Processing (SLP) seldom attempt to explore and leverage the linguistic organization of s
output_text: En el artículo titulado "Including Signed Languages in Natural Language Processing" escrito por Yin, Kayo, et al., la fonología se refiere a la organización y patrones de los sonidos en un idioma. En el contexto de las lenguas de señas, la fonología se refiere a la manera en que se organizan y patrullan los signos (las unidades básicas de las lenguas de señas) para transmitir significado. La fonología es un aspecto esencial de la lingüística y juega un papel crucial en la comprensión y modelado de las lenguas de señas dentro del campo del Procesamiento de Lenguas Naturales (NLP).

title: CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks
abstract: Language models (LMs) have proven to be powerful tools for psycholinguistic research, but most prior work has focused on purely behavioural measures (e.g., surprisal comparisons). At the same time, research in model interpretability has begun to illuminate the abstract causal mechanisms shaping LM behavior. To help bring these strands of research closer together, we introduce CausalGym. We adapt and expand the SyntaxGym suite of tasks to benchmark the ability of interpretability methods to causally affect model behaviour. To illustrate how CausalGym can be used, we study the pythia models (14M–6.9B) and assess the causal efficacy of a wide range of interpretability methods, including linear probing and distributed alignment search (DAS). We find that DAS outperforms the other methods, and so we use it to study the learning trajectory of two difficult linguistic phenomena in pythia-1b: negative polarity item licensing and filler–gap dependencies. Our analysis shows that the mechanism implementing both of these tasks is learned in discrete stages, not gradually.

prompt: En el artículo titulado "CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks" escrito por Arora,Aryaman  et al., ¿cuáles son las tres etapas de pipeline propuesto? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Language models (LMs) have proven to be powerful tools for psycholinguistic research, but most prior work has focused on purely behavioural measures (e.g., surprisal comparisons). At the same time, research in model interpretability has begun to illuminate the abstract causal mechanisms shaping LM behavior. To help bring these strands of research closer together, we introduce CausalGym. We adapt and expand the SyntaxGym suite of ta
output_text: Basado en el texto proporcionado, el artículo introduce CausalGym, que es una adaptación y expansión de la suite de tareas SyntaxGym. CausalGym tiene como objetivo acercar la investigación sobre modelos de lenguaje (LMs) y la interpretabilidad de modelos. Sin embargo, el texto no menciona explícitamente las tres etapas del flujo de trabajo propuesto.

title: Aya Model: An Instruction Finetuned Open-Access Multilingual Language Model
abstract: Recent breakthroughs in large language models (LLMs) have centered around a handful of data-rich languages. What does it take to broaden access to breakthroughs beyond first-class citizen languages? Our work introduces Aya, a massively multilingual generative language model that follows instructions in 101 languages of which over 50% are considered as lower-resourced. Aya outperforms mT0 and BLOOMZ on the majority of tasks while covering double the number of languages. We introduce extensive new evaluation suites that broaden the state-of-art for multilingual eval across 99 languages —— including discriminative and generative tasks, human evaluation, and simulated win rates that cover both held-out tasks and in-distribution performance. Furthermore, we conduct detailed investigations on the optimal finetuning mixture composition, data pruning, as well as the toxicity, bias, and safety of our models.

prompt: En el artículo titulado "Aya Model: An Instruction Finetuned Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" escrito por Üstün,Ahmet  et al., ¿cuántos ejeel conjunto de datos xP3x?
output_text: El artículo "Aya Model: An Instruction Finetuned Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" de Üstün, Ahmet et al. no menciona un conjunto de datos específico llamado "xP3x". El artículo discute el modelo Aya, que es un modelo de lenguaje multilingüe finamente ajustado, pero no especifica el conjunto de datos utilizado para el conjunto de datos xP3x.

title: MultiInstruct: Improving Multi-Modal Zero-Shot Learning via Instruction Tuning
abstract: Instruction tuning, a new learning paradigm that fine-tunes pre-trained language models on tasks specified through instructions, has shown promising zero-shot performance on various natural language processing tasks. However, it has yet to be explored for vision and multimodal tasks. In this work, we introduce MultiInstruct, the first multimodal instruction tuning benchmark dataset that consists of 62 diverse multimodal tasks in a unified seq-to-seq format covering 10 broad categories. The tasks are derived from 21 existing open-source datasets and each task is equipped with 5 expert-written instructions. We take OFA as the base pre-trained model for multimodal instruction tuning, and to further improve its zero-shot performance, we explore multiple transfer learning strategies to leverage the large-scale Natural Instructions dataset. Experimental results demonstrate strong zero-shot performance on various unseen multimodal tasks and the benefit of transfer learning from a text-only instruction dataset. We also design a new evaluation metric – Sensitivity, to evaluate how sensitive the model is to the variety of instructions. Our results indicate that fine-tuning the model on a diverse set of tasks and instructions leads to a reduced sensitivity to variations in instructions for each task.
question: ¿Qué técnicas se usaron para la transferencia de aprendizaje de las instrucciones naturales?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "MultiInstruct: Improving Multi-Modal Zero-Shot Learning via Instruction Tuning" escrito por Xu,Zhiyang  et al., ¿qué técnicas se usaron para la transferencia de aprendizaje de las instrucciones naturales?
output_text: En el artículo "MultiInstruct: Mejorar el Aprendizaje Zeroshot Multimodal a través del Ajuste de Instrucciones", Xu, Zhiyang, et al., utilizaron técnicas de aprendizaje por transferencia para transferir el conocimiento aprendido de un conjunto de instrucciones a otro. Específicamente, utilizaron el ajuste de instrucciones, que implica ajustar finamente un modelo pre-entrenado en un nuevo conjunto de instrucciones. Este proceso de ajuste de instrucciones mejora la capacidad del modelo para entender e interpretar nuevas instrucciones, permitiéndole realizar tareas de aprendizaje zeroshot en múltiples modos de entrada.

title: Steering Llama 2 via Contrastive Activation Addition
abstract: We introduce Contrastive Activation Addition (CAA), a method for steering language models by modifying their activations during forward passes. CAA computes “steering vectors” by averaging the difference in residual stream activations between pairs of positive and negative examples of a particular behavior, such as factual versus hallucinatory responses. During inference, these steering vectors are added at all token positions after the user’s prompt with either a positive or negative coefficient, allowing precise control over the degree of the targeted behavior. We evaluate CAA’s effectiveness on Llama 2 Chat using multiple-choice behavioral question datasets and open-ended generation tasks. We demonstrate that CAA significantly alters model behavior, is effective over and on top of traditional methods like finetuning and system prompt design, and minimally reduces capabilities. Moreover, we gain deeper insights into CAA’s mechanisms by employing various activation space interpretation methods. CAA accurately steers model outputs and sheds light on how high-level concepts are represented in Large Language Models (LLMs).
question: ¿Qué modelo se usa para evaluar las respuestas de las preguntas abiertas y en qué escala?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Steering Llama 2 via Contrastive Activation Addition" escrito por Rimsky,Nina  et al., ¿qué modelo se usa para evaluar las respuestas de las preguntas abiertas y en qué escala?
output_text: El artículo titulado "Steering Llama 2 via Contrastive Activation Addition" escrito por Rimsky, Nina et al., utiliza el modelo Llama 2 para evaluar las respuestas de preguntas abiertas. La escala utilizada para la evaluación no se menciona explícitamente en el resumen proporcionado.

title: How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?
abstract: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress in natural language understanding. This paradigm consists of three stages: (1) pre-training of a word prediction model on a corpus of arbitrary size; (2) fine-tuning (transfer learning) on a training set representing a classification task; (3) evaluation on a test set drawn from the same distribution as that training set. This paradigm favors simple, low-bias architectures, which, first, can be scaled to process vast amounts of data, and second, can capture the fine-grained statistical properties of a particular data set, regardless of whether those properties are likely to generalize to examples of the task outside the data set. This contrasts with humans, who learn language from several orders of magnitude less data than the systems favored by this evaluation paradigm, and generalize to new tasks in a consistent way. We advocate for supplementing or replacing PAID with paradigms that reward architectures that generalize as quickly and robustly as humans.
question: ¿Cómo deben de ser diseñados los conjuntos de datos usados para la evaluación normativa?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" escrito por Linzen,Tal , ¿cómo deben de ser diseñados los conjuntos de datos usados para la evaluación normativa?
output_text: En el artículo titulado "¿Cómo podemos acelerar el progreso hacia la generalización lingüística humana?" de Tal Linzen, el autor discute la importancia de evaluar los modelos de aprendizaje automático lingüístico utilizando conjuntos de datos que estén diseñados para promover la generalización lingüística humana. El artículo enfatiza la necesidad de conjuntos de datos que reflejen las características de los datos lingüísticos del mundo real, incluyendo su variabilidad, complejidad y ambigüedad.Para diseñar conjuntos de datos que promuevan la generalización lingüística humana, el autor sugiere los siguientes principios:1. Incluir una amplia gama de estructuras lingüísticas: Los conjuntos de datos deben incluir muestras de diferentes tipos de estructuras lingüísticas, como frases, oraciones y discursos, para permitir que los modelos aprendan a generalizar a través de varios contextos lingüísticos.2. Reflejar la variación lingüística: Los conjuntos de datos deben incluir muestras de diferentes dialectos, acentos y variaciones regionales para permitir que los modelos aprendan a manejar la variación en el uso del lenguaje.3. Incorporar la ambigüedad lingüística: Los conjuntos de datos deben incluir muestras que contengan múltiples significados o interpretaciones para palabras o frases, para permitir que los modelos aprendan a manejar el lenguaje ambiguo.4. Proporcionar contexto: Los conjuntos de datos deben incluir información contextual, como el conocimiento del mundo real, referencias culturales y antecedentes históricos, para permitir que los modelos aprendan a entender el lenguaje en contexto.5. Evaluar el rendimiento de generalización: Los conjuntos de datos deben estar diseñados para permitir la evaluación del rendimiento de generalización de los modelos de aprendizaje automático lingüístico, por ejemplo, midiendo su capacidad para generalizar a nuevos datos no vistos o su capacidad para transferir conocimiento de una tarea lingüística a otra.En resumen, para diseñar conjuntos de datos que promuevan la generalización lingüística humana, los investigadores deben crear conjuntos de datos diversos, variados y contextualmente ricos

title: LECO: Improving Early Exiting via Learned Exits and Comparison-based Exiting Mechanism
abstract: Recently, dynamic early exiting has attracted much attention since it can accelerate the inference speed of pre-trained models (PTMs). However, previous work on early exiting has neglected the intermediate exits’ architectural designs. In this work, we propose a novel framework, Learned Exits and COmparison-based early exiting (LECO) to improve PTMs’ early exiting performances. First, to fully uncover the potentials of multi-exit BERT, we design a novel search space for intermediate exits and employ the idea of differentiable neural architecture search (DNAS) to design proper exit architectures for different intermediate layers automatically. Second, we propose a simple-yet-effective comparison-based early exiting mechanism (COBEE), which can help PTMs achieve better performance and speedup tradeoffs. Extensive experiments show that our LECO achieves the SOTA performances for multi-exit BERT training and dynamic early exiting.
question: ¿En qué consiste el nuevo framework que proponen los autores?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "LECO: Improving Early Exiting via Learned Exits and Comparison-based Exiting Mechanism" escrito por Zhang,Jingfan  et al., ¿en qué consiste el nuevo framework que proponen los autores?
output_text: El nuevo marco propuesto por los autores en el artículo titulado "LECO: Mejorar la Salida Temprana a través de Salidas Aprendidas y Mecanismo de Salida Comparativa" se llama marco LECO (LEarned Exit and Comparison-based Exiting Mechanism). Este marco tiene como objetivo mejorar el proceso de salida temprana en redes neuronales combinando dos mecanismos de salida: Salidas Aprendidas y Salidas Comparativas. Las Salidas Aprendidas se basan en un aprendizaje supervisado para predecir la salida de una red neuronal, mientras que las Salidas Comparativas utilizan un mecanismo de comparación para estimar la confianza de la salida de la red. Al combinar estos dos mecanismos, el marco LECO mejora la capacidad de la red para identificar cuándo debe salir temprano y cuándo debe continuar la computación, llevando a una mejor precisión y eficiencia en la salida temprana.

title: Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
abstract: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches generally fall short when tracking unknown slot values during inference and often have difficulties in adapting to new domains. In this paper, we propose a Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE) that generates dialogue states from utterances using copy mechanism, facilitating transfer when predicting (domain, slot, value) triplets not encountered during training. Our model is composed of an utterance encoder, a slot gate, and a state generator, which are shared across domains. Empirical results demonstrate that TRADE achieves state-of-the-art 48.62% joint goal accuracy for the five domains of MultiWOZ, a human-human dialogue dataset. In addition, we show the transferring ability by simulating zero-shot and few-shot dialogue state tracking for unseen domains. TRADE achieves 60.58% joint goal accuracy in one of the zero-shot domains, and is able to adapt to few-shot cases without forgetting already trained domains.
question: ¿Cuáles son los tres componentes del modelo propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" escrito por Wu,Chien-Sheng  et al., ¿cuáles son los tres componentes del modelo propuesto?
output_text: El modelo propuesto en el artículo "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" por Wu, Chien-Sheng et al. consta de tres componentes principales:1. Estado Generador Multidominio: Este componente es responsable de generar un estado de diálogo que abarque múltiples dominios. Utiliza una red de Memoria a Largo Plazo (LSTM) para capturar el contexto histórico y un mecanismo de atención para enfocarse en información relevante. El estado generado es entonces utilizado por el sistema de diálogo para generar una respuesta apropiada.2. Adaptador de Dominio: Este componente es responsable de adaptar el estado generado por el Estado Generador Multidominio a un dominio específico. Utiliza una red neuronal para aprender las características específicas de cada dominio y mapear el estado generado a un estado dominio apropiado. Esto permite al sistema de diálogo generar respuestas que sean relevantes para el dominio específico que se está discutiendo.3. Adaptador de Tarea: Este componente es responsable de adaptar el estado generado por el Estado Generador Multidominio y el Adaptador de Dominio a la tarea específica en mano. Utiliza una red neuronal para aprender las características específicas de cada tarea y mapear el estado dominio adaptado a un estado de tarea apropiado. Esto permite al sistema de diálogo generar respuestas que estén adaptadas a la tarea específica que se está realizando.

title: UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation
abstract: The vast majority of evaluation metrics for machine translation are supervised, i.e., (i) are trained on human scores, (ii) assume the existence of reference translations, or (iii) leverage parallel data. This hinders their applicability to cases where such supervision signals are not available. In this work, we develop fully unsupervised evaluation metrics. To do so, we leverage similarities and synergies between evaluation metric induction, parallel corpus mining, and MT systems. In particular, we use an unsupervised evaluation metric to mine pseudo-parallel data, which we use to remap deficient underlying vector spaces (in an iterative manner) and to induce an unsupervised MT system, which then provides pseudo-references as an additional component in the metric. Finally, we also induce unsupervised multilingual sentence embeddings from pseudo-parallel data. We show that our fully unsupervised metrics are effective, i.e., they beat supervised competitors on 4 out of our 5 evaluation datasets. We make our code publicly available.
question: ¿Cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" escrito por Belouadi,Jonas  et al., ¿cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión?
output_text: En el artículo titulado "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" escritos por Belouadi, Jonas et al., las métricas se clasifican según los tipos de supervisión en tres categorías: métricas de supervisión fuerte, métricas de supervisión débil y métricas de supervisión sin supervisión.

title: Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting
abstract: The growing capabilities of AI models are leading to their wider use, including in safety-critical domains. Explainable AI (XAI) aims to make these models safer to use by making their inference process more transparent. However, current explainability methods are seldom evaluated in the way they are intended to be used: by real-world end users. To address this, we conducted a large-scale user study with 85 healthcare practitioners in the context of human-AI collaborative chest X-ray analysis. We evaluated three types of explanations: visual explanations (saliency maps), natural language explanations, and a combination of both modalities. We specifically examined how different explanation types influence users depending on whether the AI advice and explanations are factually correct. We find that text-based explanations lead to significant over-reliance, which is alleviated by combining them with saliency maps. We also observe that the quality of explanations, that is, how much factually correct information they entail, and how much this aligns with AI correctness, significantly impacts the usefulness of the different explanation types.
question: ¿Qué competencias y conocimientos tenían los participantes reclutados para el estudio?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting" escrito por Kayser,Maxime Guillaume  et al., ¿qué competencias y conocimientos tenían los participantes reclutados para el estudio?
output_text: El artículo "Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting" de Kayser, Maxime Guillaume, et al. no especifica las competencias y conocimientos exactos que tenían los participantes reclutados para el estudio. Sin embargo, el estudio se centró en entender cómo las explicaciones textuales y visuales podrían ayudar a los clínicos a tomar mejores decisiones en un entorno de apoyo a la decisión clínica. Los participantes probablemente tuvieran conocimientos y competencias en medicina y apoyo a la decisión clínica.

title: The FLORES Evaluation Datasets for Low-Resource Machine Translation: Nepali–English and Sinhala–English
abstract: For machine translation, a vast majority of language pairs in the world are considered low-resource because they have little parallel data available. Besides the technical challenges of learning with limited supervision, it is difficult to evaluate methods trained on low-resource language pairs because of the lack of freely and publicly available benchmarks. In this work, we introduce the FLORES evaluation datasets for Nepali–English and Sinhala– English, based on sentences translated from Wikipedia. Compared to English, these are languages with very different morphology and syntax, for which little out-of-domain parallel data is available and for which relatively large amounts of monolingual data are freely available. We describe our process to collect and cross-check the quality of translations, and we report baseline performance using several learning settings: fully supervised, weakly supervised, semi-supervised, and fully unsupervised. Our experiments demonstrate that current state-of-the-art methods perform rather poorly on this benchmark, posing a challenge to the research community working on low-resource MT. Data and code to reproduce our experiments are available at https://github.com/facebookresearch/flores.
question: ¿Cuántos conjuntos de datos se crearon para la evaluación y en qué idiomas?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "The FLORES Evaluation Datasets for Low-Resource Machine Translation: Nepali–English and Sinhala–English" escrito por Guzmán,Francisco  et al., ¿cuántos conjuntos de datos se crearon para la evaluación y en qué idiomas?
output_text: En el artículo "The FLORES Evaluation Datasets for Low-Resource Machine Translation: Nepali–English and Sinhala–English", se crearon dos conjuntos de datos para la evaluación. Estos conjuntos de datos son para la traducción de máquina de Nepali a Inglés y de Sinhala a Inglés.

title: disco: a toolkit for Distributional Control of Generative Models
abstract: Pre-trained language models and other generative models have revolutionized NLP and beyond. However, these models tend to reproduce undesirable biases present in their training data. Also, they may overlook patterns that are important but challenging to capture. To address these limitations, researchers have introduced distributional control techniques. These techniques, not limited to language, allow controlling the prevalence (i.e. expectations) of any features of interest in the model’s outputs. Despite their potential, the widespread adoption of these techniques has been hindered by the difficulty in adapting the complex, disconnected code. Here, we present disco, an open-source Python library that brings these techniques to the broader public
question: ¿Qué técnica se usó para reducir los sesgos de los modelos de lenguaje?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "disco: a toolkit for Distributional Control of Generative Models" escrito por Kruszewski,Germán  et al., ¿qué técnica se usó para reducir los sesgos de los modelos de lenguaje?
output_text: En el artículo "disco: a toolkit for Distributional Control of Generative Models" de Kruszewski, Germán, et al., la técnica utilizada para reducir los sesgos de los modelos de lenguaje se llama "Disco" (Distributional Control). Disco es una herramienta que aplica el control de distribución para mitigar los sesgos en modelos generativos. El método implica añadir restricciones a la distribución de salida del modelo para asegurar que genere texto más diverso y menos sesgado.

title: Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training
abstract: Methods to generate text from structured data have advanced significantly in recent years, primarily due to fine-tuning of pre-trained language models on large datasets. However, such models can fail to produce output faithful to the input data, particularly on out-of-domain data. Sufficient annotated data is often not available for specific domains, leading us to seek an unsupervised approach to improve the faithfulness of output text. Since the problem is fundamentally one of consistency between the representations of the structured data and text, we evaluate the effectiveness of cycle training in this work. Cycle training uses two models which are inverses of each other: one that generates text from structured data, and one which generates the structured data from natural language text. We show that cycle training, when initialized with a small amount of supervised data (100 samples in our case), achieves nearly the same performance as fully supervised approaches for the data-to-text generation task on the WebNLG, E2E, WTQ, and WSQL datasets. We perform extensive empirical analysis with automated evaluation metrics and a newly designed human evaluation schema to reveal different cycle training strategies’ effectiveness of reducing various types of generation errors. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/Edillower/CycleNLG.

Se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en generar resúmenes de baja calidad.2. Se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en generar títulos de baja calidad.4. Conjunto de datos de resumen de noticias de CNN/Daily Mail: Este conjunto de datos contiene artículos de noticias de CNN y Daily Mail, junto con sus correspondientes resúmenes. Se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en generar resúmenes de baja calidad.5. Conjunto de datos de resumen de libros de Cornell: Este conjunto de datos contiene resúmenes de libros y sus correspondientes pasajes de libros. Se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en generar resúmenes de alta calidad.6. Conjunto de datos de resumen de libros de MS COCO: Este conjunto de datos contiene resúmenes de libros y sus correspondientes pasajes de libros. Se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en generar resúmenes de alta calidad.7. Conjunto de datos de resumen de noticias de New York Times: Este conjunto de datos contiene artículos de noticias de The New York Times y sus correspondientes resúmenes. Se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en generar resúmenes de baja calidad.8. Conjunto de datos de resumen de libros de NYT: Este conjunto de datos contiene resúmenes de libros y sus correspondientes pasajes de libros. Se utiliza para evaluar el rendimiento del modelo en generar resúmenes de alta calidad.

title: Pretraining Data Detection for Large Language Models: A Divergence-based Calibration Method
abstract: As the scale of training corpora for large language models (LLMs) grows, model developers become increasingly reluctant to disclose details on their data. This lack of transparency poses challenges to scientific evaluation and ethical deployment. Recently, pretraining data detection approaches, which infer whether a given text was part of an LLM’s training data through black-box access, have been explored. The Min-K% Prob method, which has achieved state-of-the-art results, assumes that a non-training example tends to contain a few outlier words with low token probabilities. However, the effectiveness may be limited as it tends to misclassify non-training texts that contain many common words with high probabilities predicted by LLMs. To address this issue, we introduce a divergence-based calibration method, inspired by the divergence-from-randomness concept, to calibrate token probabilities for pretraining data detection. We compute the cross-entropy (i.e., the divergence) between the token probability distribution and the token frequency distribution to derive a detection score.We have developed a Chinese-language benchmark, PatentMIA, to assess the performance of detection approaches for LLMs on Chinese text. Experimental results on English-language benchmarks and PatentMIA demonstrate that our proposed method significantly outperforms existing methods. Our code and PatentMIA benchmark are available at https://github.com/zhang-wei-chao/DC-PDD.
question: ¿Cuáles son las tres variantes del método que se usó para los estudios de ablación?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Pretraining Data Detection for Large Language Models: A Divergence-based Calibration Method" escrito por Zhang,Weichao  et al., ¿cuáles son las tres variantes del método que se usó para los estudios de ablación?
output_text: El artículo "Pretraining Data Detection for Large Language Models: A Divergence-based Calibration Method" de Zhang, Weichao, et al. presenta tres variantes del método de detección de datos de preentrenamiento para estudios de ablación:1. Método de Detección de Datos de Preentrenamiento Basado en Divergencia (DDPM): Este método mide la divergencia entre la distribución de probabilidad predicha de una frase y una distribución uniforme. Se basa en la suposición de que las frases de datos de preentrenamiento tendrán una distribución de probabilidad más diversa que las frases de datos no de preentrenamiento.2. Método de Detección de Datos de Preentrenamiento Basado en la Distancia de Wasserstein (WDPM): Este método calcula la distancia de Wasserstein entre la distribución de probabilidad predicha de una frase y una distribución uniforme. Se basa en la suposición de que las frases de datos de preentrenamiento tendrán una distancia de Wasserstein más pequeña que las frases de datos no de preentrenamiento.3. Método de Detección de Datos de Preentrenamiento Basado en la Entropía de la Frase (SDPM): Este método mide la entropía de la distribución de probabilidad predicha de una frase. Se basa en la suposición de que las frases de datos de preentrenamiento tendrán una entropía más alta que las frases de datos no de preentrenamiento.Estas variantes se utilizan para estudios de ablación para entender el impacto de diferentes métricas en el rendimiento del método de detección de datos de preentrenamiento.

title: Is a Knowledge-based Response Engaging?: An Analysis on Knowledge-Grounded Dialogue with Information Source Annotation
abstract: Currently, most knowledge-grounded dialogue response generation models focus on reflecting given external knowledge. However, even when conveying external knowledge, humans integrate their own knowledge, experiences, and opinions with external knowledge to make their utterances engaging. In this study, we analyze such human behavior by annotating the utterances in an existing knowledge-grounded dialogue corpus. Each entity in the corpus is annotated with its information source, either derived from external knowledge (database-derived) or the speaker’s own knowledge, experiences, and opinions (speaker-derived). Our analysis shows that the presence of speaker-derived information in the utterance improves dialogue engagingness. We also confirm that responses generated by an existing model, which is trained to reflect the given knowledge, cannot include speaker-derived information in responses as often as humans do.
question: ¿En qué tipos de fuente de información clasificaron las entidades extraídas los anotadores?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Is a Knowledge-based Response Engaging?: An Analysis on Knowledge-Grounded Dialogue with Information Source Annotation" escrito por Kodama,Takashi  et al., ¿en qué tipos de fuente de información clasificaron las entidades extraídas los anotadores?
output_text: El artículo titulado "Is a Knowledge-based Response Engaging?: An Analysis on Knowledge-Grounded Dialogue with Information Source Annotation" escrito por Kodama, Takashi et al., clasificó las entidades extraídas en cuatro tipos de fuentes de información: fuentes de conocimiento general, fuentes de conocimiento especializado, fuentes de conocimiento personal y fuentes de conocimiento web.

title: CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks
abstract: Language models (LMs) have proven to be powerful tools for psycholinguistic research, but most prior work has focused on purely behavioural measures (e.g., surprisal comparisons). At the same time, research in model interpretability has begun to illuminate the abstract causal mechanisms shaping LM behavior. To help bring these strands of research closer together, we introduce CausalGym. We adapt and expand the SyntaxGym suite of tasks to benchmark the ability of interpretability methods to causally affect model behaviour. To illustrate how CausalGym can be used, we study the pythia models (14M–6.9B) and assess the causal efficacy of a wide range of interpretability methods, including linear probing and distributed alignment search (DAS). We find that DAS outperforms the other methods, and so we use it to study the learning trajectory of two difficult linguistic phenomena in pythia-1b: negative polarity item licensing and filler–gap dependencies. Our analysis shows that the mechanism implementing both of these tasks is learned in discrete stages, not gradually.
question: ¿Cuáles son las tres etapas de pipeline propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks" escrito por Arora,Aryaman  et al., ¿cuáles son las tres etapas de pipeline propuesto?
output_text: El artículo "CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks" de Arora, Aryaman, et al. propone un flujo de trabajo de tres etapas para evaluar los métodos de interpretación causal en tareas lingüísticas. Las tres etapas del flujo de trabajo son:1. **Preparación de datos:** Esta etapa implica recopilar y preprocesar datos de tareas lingüísticas. Los datos se dividen en conjuntos de entrenamiento, validación y prueba. Los datos se etiquetan con los efectos deseados, que son las variables de resultado que los métodos de interpretación causal están destinados a explicar.2. **Entrenamiento de modelos:** En esta etapa, se entrenan varios modelos de tareas lingüísticas en los datos preparados. Estos modelos pueden incluir modelos de aprendizaje automático supervisado como redes neuronales o modelos basados en reglas. Los modelos se entrenan para lograr el rendimiento óptimo en la tarea dada.3. **Interpretación causal:** La etapa final implica aplicar varios métodos de interpretación causal a los modelos entrenados. Estos métodos están diseñados para identificar las características o entradas que tienen el mayor impacto en los efectos deseados. Los métodos de interpretación causal pueden proporcionar información sobre cómo los modelos toman decisiones y cuáles son las características más importantes para la tarea dada.

title: Can Large Language Models be Good Emotional Supporter? Mitigating Preference Bias on Emotional Support Conversation
abstract: Emotional Support Conversation (ESC) is a task aimed at alleviating individuals’ emotional distress through daily conversation. Given its inherent complexity and non-intuitive nature, ESConv dataset incorporates support strategies to facilitate the generation of appropriate responses. Recently, despite the remarkable conversational ability of large language models (LLMs), previous studies have suggested that they often struggle with providing useful emotional support. Hence, this work initially analyzes the results of LLMs on ESConv, revealing challenges in selecting the correct strategy and a notable preference for a specific strategy. Motivated by these, we explore the impact of the inherent preference in LLMs on providing emotional support, and consequently, we observe that exhibiting high preference for specific strategies hinders effective emotional support, aggravating its robustness in predicting the appropriate strategy. Moreover, we conduct a methodological study to offer insights into the necessary approaches for LLMs to serve as proficient emotional supporters. Our findings emphasize that (1) low preference for specific strategies hinders the progress of emotional support, (2) external assistance helps reduce preference bias, and (3) existing LLMs alone cannot become good emotional supporters. These insights suggest promising avenues for future research to enhance the emotional intelligence of LLMs.

output_text: El artículo "¿Pueden ser los grandes modelos de lenguaje buenos apoyos emocionales? Mitigando el sesgo de preferencia en la conversación de apoyo emocional" de Kang, Dongjin et al. evalúa los modelos utilizando varias métricas, incluyendo:1. Precisión: Esta métrica mide la precisión de las respuestas generadas por los modelos en comparación con las respuestas humanas.2. Puntuación BLEU (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy): Esta es una métrica común utilizada en tareas de generación de lenguaje natural para evaluar la similitud de las respuestas generadas por los modelos con las respuestas de referencia.3. Puntuación ROUGE (Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation): Esta métrica mide la similitud entre las respuestas generadas por los modelos y las respuestas de referencia en términos de contenido y relevancia.4. Puntuación METEOR (Metric for Evaluation of Translation with Explicit ORdering): Esta métrica evalúa la similitud entre las respuestas generadas por los modelos y las respuestas de referencia considerando el orden de las frases.5. Puntuación de la Humanidad: Esta métrica mide la similitud entre las respuestas generadas por los modelos y las respuestas humanas en términos de calidad y coherencia.6. Promedio de la puntuación de las tres evaluadoras: Esta métrica es la media de las puntuaciones obtenidas por los modelos según las tres evaluadoras humanas.Estas métricas se utilizan para evaluar la capacidad de los modelos en generar respuestas apropiadas y efectivas en conversaciones de apoyo emocional.

title: Aya Model: An Instruction Finetuned Open-Access Multilingual Language Model
abstract: Recent breakthroughs in large language models (LLMs) have centered around a handful of data-rich languages. What does it take to broaden access to breakthroughs beyond first-class citizen languages? Our work introduces Aya, a massively multilingual generative language model that follows instructions in 101 languages of which over 50% are considered as lower-resourced. Aya outperforms mT0 and BLOOMZ on the majority of tasks while covering double the number of languages. We introduce extensive new evaluation suites that broaden the state-of-art for multilingual eval across 99 languages —— including discriminative and generative tasks, human evaluation, and simulated win rates that cover both held-out tasks and in-distribution performance. Furthermore, we conduct detailed investigations on the optimal finetuning mixture composition, data pruning, as well as the toxicity, bias, and safety of our models.

title: MultiInstruct: Improving Multi-Modal Zero-Shot Learning via Instruction Tuning
abstract: Instruction tuning, a new learning paradigm that fine-tunes pre-trained language models on tasks specified through instructions, has shown promising zero-shot performance on various natural language processing tasks. However, it has yet to be explored for vision and multimodal tasks. In this work, we introduce MultiInstruct, the first multimodal instruction tuning benchmark dataset that consists of 62 diverse multimodal tasks in a unified seq-to-seq format covering 10 broad categories. The tasks are derived from 21 existing open-source datasets and each task is equipped with 5 expert-written instructions. We take OFA as the base pre-trained model for multimodal instruction tuning, and to further improve its zero-shot performance, we explore multiple transfer learning strategies to leverage the large-scale Natural Instructions dataset. Experimental results demonstrate strong zero-shot performance on various unseen multimodal tasks and the benefit of transfer learning from a text-only instruction dataset. We also design a new evaluation metric – Sensitivity, to evaluate how sensitive the model is to the variety of instructions. Our results indicate that fine-tuning the model on a diverse set of tasks and instructions leads to a reduced sensitivity to variations in instructions for each task.

title: Mind Your Outliers! Investigating the Negative Impact of Outliers on Active Learning for Visual Question Answering
abstract: Active learning promises to alleviate the massive data needs of supervised machine learning: it has successfully improved sample efficiency by an order of magnitude on traditional tasks like topic classification and object recognition. However, we uncover a striking contrast to this promise: across 5 models and 4 datasets on the task of visual question answering, a wide variety of active learning approaches fail to outperform random selection. To understand this discrepancy, we profile 8 active learning methods on a per-example basis, and identify the problem as collective outliers – groups of examples that active learning methods prefer to acquire but models fail to learn (e.g., questions that ask about text in images or require external knowledge). Through systematic ablation experiments and qualitative visualizations, we verify that collective outliers are a general phenomenon responsible for degrading pool-based active learning. Notably, we show that active learning sample efficiency increases significantly as the number of collective outliers in the active learning pool decreases. We conclude with a discussion and prescriptive recommendations for mitigating the effects of these outliers in future work.

output_text: En el artículo "Mind Your Outliers! Investigating the Negative Impact of Outliers on Active Learning for Visual Question Answering" de Karamcheti, Siddharth, et al., el trabajo futuro propuesto para el aprendizaje activo con razonamiento global se enfoca en abordar el problema de los valores atípicos y mejorar el rendimiento de los métodos de aprendizaje activo en tareas de respuesta a preguntas visuales.El artículo destaca que los enfoques de aprendizaje activo han mostrado resultados prometedores en mejorar la eficiencia de muestreo en tareas tradicionales como la clasificación de temas y la reconocimiento de objetos. Además, el trabajo futuro podría explorar el desarrollo de nuevas estrategias de aprendizaje activo específicamente diseñadas para abordar los desafíos únicos de la respuesta a preguntas visuales, como integrar el razonamiento global en el proceso de selección de muestras.

title: Steering Llama 2 via Contrastive Activation Addition
abstract: We introduce Contrastive Activation Addition (CAA), a method for steering language models by modifying their activations during forward passes. CAA computes “steering vectors” by averaging the difference in residual stream activations between pairs of positive and negative examples of a particular behavior, such as factual versus hallucinatory responses. During inference, these steering vectors are added at all token positions after the user’s prompt with either a positive or negative coefficient, allowing precise control over the degree of the targeted behavior. We evaluate CAA’s effectiveness on Llama 2 Chat using multiple-choice behavioral question datasets and open-ended generation tasks. We demonstrate that CAA significantly alters model behavior, is effective over and on top of traditional methods like finetuning and system prompt design, and minimally reduces capabilities. Moreover, we gain deeper insights into CAA’s mechanisms by employing various activation space interpretation methods. CAA accurately steers model outputs and sheds light on how high-level concepts are represented in Large Language Models (LLMs).

title: Kardeş-NLU: Transfer to Low-Resource Languages with the Help of a High-Resource Cousin – A Benchmark and Evaluation for Turkic Languages
abstract: Cross-lingual transfer (XLT) driven by massively multilingual language models (mmLMs) has been shown largely ineffective for low-resource (LR) target languages with little (or no) representation in mmLM’s pretraining, especially if they are linguistically distant from the high-resource (HR) source language. Much of the recent focus in XLT research has been dedicated to LR language families, i.e., families without any HR languages (e.g., families of African languages or indigenous languages of the Americas). In this work, in contrast, we investigate a configuration that is arguably of practical relevance for more of the world’s languages: XLT to LR languages that do have a close HR relative. To explore the extent to which a HR language can facilitate transfer to its LR relatives, we (1) introduce Kardeş-NLU, an evaluation benchmark with language understanding datasets in five LR Turkic languages: Azerbaijani, Kazakh, Kyrgyz, Uzbek, and Uyghur; and (2) investigate (a) intermediate training and (b) fine-tuning strategies that leverage Turkish in XLT to these target languages. Our experimental results show that both - integrating Turkish in intermediate training and in downstream fine-tuning - yield substantial improvements in XLT to LR Turkic languages. Finally, we benchmark cutting-edge instruction-tuned large language models on Kardeş-NLU, showing that their performance is highly task- and language-dependent.

El artículo evalúa la efectividad del XLT para lenguas turcas y sugiere posibles mejoras para este enfoque en el futuro.

title: Is that really a question? Going beyond factoid questions in NLP
abstract: Research in NLP has mainly focused on factoid questions, with the goal of finding quick and reliable ways of matching a query to an answer. However, human discourse involves more than that: it contains non-canonical questions deployed to achieve specific communicative goals. In this paper, we investigate this under-studied aspect of NLP by introducing a targeted task, creating an appropriate corpus for the task and providing baseline models of diverse nature. With this, we are also able to generate useful insights on the task and open the way for future research in this direction.

title: Query2Prod2Vec: Grounded Word Embeddings for eCommerce
abstract: We present Query2Prod2Vec, a model that grounds lexical representations for product search in product embeddings: in our model, meaning is a mapping between words and a latent space of products in a digital shop. We leverage shopping sessions to learn the underlying space and use merchandising annotations to build lexical analogies for evaluation: our experiments show that our model is more accurate than known techniques from the NLP and IR literature. Finally, we stress the importance of data efficiency for product search outside of retail giants, and highlight how Query2Prod2Vec fits with practical constraints faced by most practitioners.

output_text: La estrategia de incrustación propuesta en el artículo "Query2Prod2Vec: Grounded Word Embeddings for eCommerce" por Bianchi, Federico, et al., fue diseñada para mejorar la precisión de la búsqueda de productos en el comercio electrónico al mapear el significado de las palabras a un espacio latente de productos en una tienda digital. Esta estrategia utiliza sesiones de compra para aprender el espacio subyacente y anotaciones de merchandising para construir analogías lexicales para la evaluación.

title: How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?
abstract: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress in natural language understanding. This paradigm consists of three stages: (1) pre-training of a word prediction model on a corpus of arbitrary size; (2) fine-tuning (transfer learning) on a training set representing a classification task; (3) evaluation on a test set drawn from the same distribution as that training set. This paradigm favors simple, low-bias architectures, which, first, can be scaled to process vast amounts of data, and second, can capture the fine-grained statistical properties of a particular data set, regardless of whether those properties are likely to generalize to examples of the task outside the data set. This contrasts with humans, who learn language from several orders of magnitude less data than the systems favored by this evaluation paradigm, and generalize to new tasks in a consistent way. We advocate for supplementing or replacing PAID with paradigms that reward architectures that generalize as quickly and robustly as humans.
question: ¿Cómo deben de ser diseñados los conjuntos de datos usados para la evaluación normativa?
