abstract: The vast majority of evaluation metrics for machine translation are supervised, i.e., (i) are trained on human scores, (ii) assume the existence of reference translations, or (iii) leverage parallel data. This hinders their applicability to cases where such supervision signals are not available. In this work, we develop fully unsupervised evaluation metrics. To do so, we leverage similarities and synergies between evaluation metric induction, parallel corpus mining, and MT systems. In particular, we use an unsupervised evaluation metric to mine pseudo-parallel data, which we use to remap deficient underlying vector spaces (in an iterative manner) and to induce an unsupervised MT system, which then provides pseudo-references as an additional component in the metric. Finally, we also induce unsupervised multilingual sentence embeddings from pseudo-parallel data. We show that our fully unsupervised metrics are effective, i.e., they beat supervised competitors on 4 out of our 5 evaluation datasets. We make our code publicly available.
question: ¿Cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" escrito por Belouadi,Jonas  et al., ¿cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión?
output_text: En el artículo "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" de Belouadi, Jonas et al., las métricas de evaluación de traducción automática se clasifican según los tipos de supervisión en tres categorías:1. **Supervision**: Métricas que requieren datos de entrenamiento etiquetados, es decir, pares de texto fuente-destino. Estas métricas son comunes en la evaluación de traducción automática y se basan en la similitud entre la traducción generada y el texto etiquetado. Ejemplos de métricas de supervisión son BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE y TER.2. **Weak Supervision**: Métricas que requieren datos de entrenamiento parcialmente etiquetados, es decir, pares de texto fuente-destino con algunas palabras o frases etiquetadas. Estas métricas son menos comunes que las de supervisión y se basan en la similitud entre la traducción generada y las palabras o frases etiquetadas. Ejemplos de métricas de weak supervision no se mencionan en el artículo.3. **Unsupervised**: Métricas que no requieren datos de entrenamiento etiquetados y se basan en la similitud entre la traducción generada y el texto fuente o el texto destino. Estas métricas son menos comunes que las de supervisión y se basan en la similitud entre la traducción generada y el texto fuente o destino. El UScore es un ejemplo de métrica de evaluación no supervisada presentada en el artículo.En resumen, el artículo clasifica las métricas de evaluación de traducción automática en tres categorías según el tipo de supervisión requerido: supervisión, weak supervision y no supervisión.

title: MultiPICo: Multilingual Perspectivist Irony Corpus
abstract: Recently, several scholars have contributed to the growth of a new theoretical framework in NLP called perspectivism. This approach aimsto leverage data annotated by different individuals to model diverse perspectives that affect their opinions on subjective phenomena such as irony. In this context, we propose MultiPICo, a multilingual perspectivist corpus of ironic short conversations in different languages andlinguistic varieties extracted from Twitter and Reddit. The corpus includes sociodemographic information about its annotators. Our analysis of the annotated corpus shows how different demographic cohorts may significantly disagree on their annotation of irony and how certain cultural factors influence the perception of the phenomenon and the agreement on the annotation. Moreover, we show how disaggregated annotations and rich annotator metadata can be exploited to benchmark the ability of large language models to recognize irony, their positionality with respect to sociodemographic groups, and the efficacy of perspective-taking prompting for irony detection in multiple languages.
question: ¿Cómo se aseguró la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "MultiPICo: Multilingual Perspectivist Irony Corpus" escrito por Casola,Silvia  et al., ¿cómo se aseguró la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus propuesto?
output_text: Según el artículo "MultiPICo: Multilingual Perspectivist Irony Corpus" de Casola, Silvia et al., la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus se aseguró a través de varios pasos:1. **Pre-annotation**: Antes de la creación del corpus, se realizó una revisión exhaustiva de la literatura sobre ironía y perspectivismo para definir las categorías y las reglas de anotación.2. **Anotación manual**: Un equipo de anotadores expertos en lingüística y literatura, con dominio de varios idiomas, realizó la anotación manual de las textos. Los anotadores recibieron entrenamiento y orientación para garantizar la consistencia y la precisión en la anotación.3. **Revisión y validación**: Una vez realizadas las anotaciones, se llevó a cabo una revisión exhaustiva de las anotaciones por parte de otros anotadores y expertos en el campo. Esto permitió identificar y corregir errores, y garantizar la consistencia y la precisión en la anotación.4. **Evaluación de la precisión**: Se realizó una evaluación de la precisión de las anotaciones mediante la comparación con las anotaciones realizadas por otros anotadores y expertos. Esto permitió medir la consistencia y la precisión en la anotación.5. **Anotación en diferentes idiomas**: Para garantizar la calidad de las anotaciones en diferentes idiomas, se utilizaron anotadores bilingües o multilingües que dominaban los idiomas en cuestión.6. **Uso de herramientas de anotación especializadas**: Se utilizó software de anotación especializado para facilitar la tarea de anotación y reducir el riesgo de errores.En resumen, la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus MultiPICo se aseguró a través de una combinación de técnicas de anotación manual, revisión y validación, evaluación de la precisión y uso de herramientas de anotación especializadas.

title: Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting
abstract: The growing capabilities of AI models are leading to their wider use, including in safety-critical domains. Explainable AI (XAI) aims to make these models safer to use by making their inference process more transparent. However, current explainability methods are seldom evaluated in the way they are intended to be used: by real-world end users. To address this, we conducted a large-scale user study with 85 healthcare practitioners in the context of human-AI collaborative chest X-ray analysis. We evaluated three types of explanations: visual explanations (saliency maps), natural language explanations, and a combination of both modalities. We specifically examined how different explanation types influence users depending on whether the AI advice and explanations are factually correct. We find that text-based explanations lead to significant over-reliance, which is alleviated by combining them with saliency maps. We also observe that the quality of explanations, that is, how much factually correct information they entail, and how much this aligns with AI correctness, significantly impacts the usefulness of the different explanation types.
question: ¿Qué competencias y conocimientos tenían los participantes reclutados para el estudio?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting" escrito por Kayser,Maxime Guillaume  et al., ¿qué competencias y conocimientos tenían los participantes reclutados para el estudio?
output_text: Según el artículo "Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting" de Kayser, Maxime Guillaume et al., los participantes reclutados para el estudio fueron médicos y residentes de medicina que trabajaban en un hospital universitario. Los autores no especifican la cantidad de participantes, pero indican que se trataba de un grupo heterogéneo de profesionales de la salud.En cuanto a las competencias y conocimientos de los participantes, se puede inferir lo siguiente:* Eran médicos y residentes de medicina, lo que sugiere que tenían una formación sólida en medicina y conocimientos generales de la salud.* Trabajaban en un hospital universitario, lo que implica que estaban familiarizados con la práctica médica en un entorno académico y de alta complejidad.* Fueron reclutados para participar en un estudio sobre decisiones de apoyo clínico, lo que sugiere que estaban interesados en la aplicación de la tecnología en la toma de decisiones clínicas y tenían experiencia en la utilización de sistemas de apoyo a la toma de decisiones.En resumen, los participantes del estudio tenían una formación en medicina y experiencia en la práctica médica, lo que les permitió evaluar y comparar las explicaciones textuales y visuales en un entorno clínico.

title: Multi-party Multimodal Conversations Between Patients, Their Companions, and a Social Robot in a Hospital Memory Clinic
abstract: We have deployed an LLM-based spoken dialogue system in a real hospital. The ARI social robot embodies our system, which patients and their companions can have multi-party conversations with together. In order to enable this multi-party ability, multimodality is critical. Our system, therefore, receives speech and video as input, and generates both speech and gestures (arm, head, and eye movements). In this paper, we describe our complex setting and the architecture of our dialogue system. Each component is detailed, and a video of the full system is available with the appropriate components highlighted in real-time. Our system decides when it should take its turn, generates human-like clarification requests when the patient pauses mid-utterance, answers in-domain questions (grounding to the in-prompt knowledge), and responds appropriately to out-of-domain requests (like generating jokes or quizzes). This latter feature is particularly remarkable as real patients often utter unexpected sentences that could not be handled previously.
question: ¿Qué tipo de datos genera el modelo propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Multi-party Multimodal Conversations Between Patients, Their Companions, and a Social Robot in a Hospital Memory Clinic" escrito por Addlesee,Angus  et al., ¿qué tipo de datos genera el modelo propuesto?
output_text: Según el artículo "Multi-party Multimodal Conversations Between Patients, Their Companions, and a Social Robot in a Hospital Memory Clinic" de Addlesee et al., el modelo propuesto genera datos multimodales, es decir, combina información de diferentes modalidades sensoriales y comunicativas.En particular, el modelo utiliza un sistema de captura de datos que incluye:1. Audio: graba las conversaciones entre pacientes, compañeros y el robot social.2. Video: registra las expresiones faciales y corporales de los participantes.3. Texto: transcribe las conversaciones en texto para análisis posterior.4. ECG: registra los señales electrocardiográficas de los participantes.Estos datos multimodales permiten analizar la interacción entre los participantes y el robot social, lo que puede ser útil para evaluar la efectividad del robot en la terapia y la comunicación en entornos de cuidado de la salud.

title: The FLORES Evaluation Datasets for Low-Resource Machine Translation: Nepali–English and Sinhala–English
abstract: For machine translation, a vast majority of language pairs in the world are considered low-resource because they have little parallel data available. Besides the technical challenges of learning with limited supervision, it is difficult to evaluate methods trained on low-resource language pairs because of the lack of freely and publicly available benchmarks. In this work, we introduce the FLORES evaluation datasets for Nepali–English and Sinhala– English, based on sentences translated from Wikipedia. Compared to English, these are languages with very different morphology and syntax, for which little out-of-domain parallel data is available and for which relatively large amounts of monolingual data are freely available. We describe our process to collect and cross-check the quality of translations, and we report baseline performance using several learning settings: fully supervised, weakly supervised, semi-supervised, and fully unsupervised. Our experiments demonstrate that current state-of-the-art methods perform rather poorly on this benchmark, posing a challenge to the research community working on low-resource MT. Data and code to reproduce our experiments are available at https://github.com/facebookresearch/flores.
question: ¿Cuántos conjuntos de datos se crearon para la evaluación y en qué idiomas?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "The FLORES Evaluation Datasets for Low-Resource Machine Translation: Nepali–English and Sinhala–English" escrito por Guzmán,Francisco  et al., ¿cuántos conjuntos de datos se crearon para la evaluación y en qué idiomas?
output_text: Según el artículo "The FLORES Evaluation Datasets for Low-Resource Machine Translation: Nepali–English and Sinhala–English" de Guzmán, Francisco et al., se crearon dos conjuntos de datos para la evaluación de la traducción automática en lenguas con recursos limitados.Los dos conjuntos de datos se crearon para la traducción entre:1. Nepali y inglés (Nepali-English)2. Sinhala y inglés (Sinhala-English)En otras palabras, se crearon dos pares de conjuntos de datos para evaluar la traducción automática entre Nepali y inglés, y entre Sinhala y inglés.

title: Question-Answering in a Low-resourced Language: Benchmark Dataset and Models for Tigrinya
abstract: Question-Answering (QA) has seen significant advances recently, achieving near human-level performance over some benchmarks. However, these advances focus on high-resourced languages such as English, while the task remains unexplored for most other languages, mainly due to the lack of annotated datasets. This work presents a native QA dataset for an East African language, Tigrinya. The dataset contains 10.6K question-answer pairs spanning 572 paragraphs extracted from 290 news articles on various topics. The dataset construction method is discussed, which is applicable to constructing similar resources for related languages. We present comprehensive experiments and analyses of several resource-efficient approaches to QA, including monolingual, cross-lingual, and multilingual setups, along with comparisons against machine-translated silver data. Our strong baseline models reach 76% in the F1 score, while the estimated human performance is 92%, indicating that the benchmark presents a good challenge for future work. We make the dataset, models, and leaderboard publicly available.
question: ¿De qué origen es el idioma de la base de datos propuesta por los autores?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Question-Answering in a Low-resourced Language: Benchmark Dataset and Models for Tigrinya" escrito por Gaim,Fitsum  et al., ¿de qué origen es el idioma de la base de datos propuesta por los autores?
output_text: Según el artículo "Question-Answering in a Low-resourced Language: Benchmark Dataset and Models for Tigrinya" escrito por Gaim, Fitsum, et al., el idioma Tigrinya es una lengua afroasiática originaria de Eritrea y Etiopía.

title: Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck
abstract: Pre-trained word embeddings like ELMo and BERT contain rich syntactic and semantic information, resulting in state-of-the-art performance on various tasks. We propose a very fast variational information bottleneck (VIB) method to nonlinearly compress these embeddings, keeping only the information that helps a discriminative parser. We compress each word embedding to either a discrete tag or a continuous vector. In the discrete version, our automatically compressed tags form an alternative tag set: we show experimentally that our tags capture most of the information in traditional POS tag annotations, but our tag sequences can be parsed more accurately at the same level of tag granularity. In the continuous version, we show experimentally that moderately compressing the word embeddings by our method yields a more accurate parser in 8 of 9 languages, unlike simple dimensionality reduction.
question: ¿Qué modelo pre-entrenado se usó para los datos en inglés?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck" escrito por Li,Xiang Lisa  et al., ¿qué modelo pre-entrenado se usó para los datos en inglés?
output_text: Según el artículo "Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck" de Li, Xiang Lisa et al., el modelo pre-entrenado utilizado para los datos en inglés es Word2Vec (CBOW) con una dimensión de 300.

title: Don’t Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments
abstract: A key missing capacity of current language models (LMs) is grounding to real-world environments. Most existing work for grounded language understanding uses LMs to directly generate plans that can be executed in the environment to achieve the desired effects. It thereby casts the burden of ensuring grammaticality, faithfulness, and controllability all on the LMs. We propose Pangu, a generic framework for grounded language understanding that capitalizes on the discriminative ability of LMs instead of their generative ability. Pangu consists of a symbolic agent and a neural LM working in a concerted fashion: The agent explores the environment to incrementally construct valid plans, and the LM evaluates the plausibility of the candidate plans to guide the search process. A case study on the challenging problem of knowledge base question answering (KBQA), which features a massive environment, demonstrates the remarkable effectiveness and flexibility of Pangu: A BERT-base LM is sufficient for setting a new record on standard KBQA datasets, and larger LMs further bring substantial gains.Pangu also enables, for the first time, effective few-shot in-context learning for KBQA with large LMs such as Codex.
question: ¿Cuáles son los dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje que discuten los autores?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Don’t Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments" escrito por Gu,Yu  et al., ¿cuáles son los dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje que discuten los autores?
output_text: Según el artículo "Don’t Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments" de Gu, Yu, et al., los autores discuten dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje:1. **Generative learning**: En este tipo de aprendizaje, los modelos de lenguaje se centran en generar texto o respuestas que sean coherentes y plausibles, pero no necesariamente veraces. Estos modelos aprenden a producir texto que sea similar a lo que se ha visto antes, lo que puede llevar a la generación de contenido que no está basado en la realidad.2. **Discriminative learning**: En este tipo de aprendizaje, los modelos de lenguaje se centran en discriminar entre respuestas correctas y incorrectas, es decir, en distinguir entre respuestas que son verdaderas y falsas. Estos modelos aprenden a evaluar la veracidad de las respuestas y a producir respuestas que sean precisas y basadas en la realidad.Los autores argumentan que los modelos de lenguaje deben ser entrenados para aprender a discriminar entre respuestas correctas e incorrectas, en lugar de simplemente generar texto, para mejorar su capacidad para producir respuestas precisas y basadas en la realidad.

title: Is a Knowledge-based Response Engaging?: An Analysis on Knowledge-Grounded Dialogue with Information Source Annotation
abstract: Currently, most knowledge-grounded dialogue response generation models focus on reflecting given external knowledge. However, even when conveying external knowledge, humans integrate their own knowledge, experiences, and opinions with external knowledge to make their utterances engaging. In this study, we analyze such human behavior by annotating the utterances in an existing knowledge-grounded dialogue corpus. Each entity in the corpus is annotated with its information source, either derived from external knowledge (database-derived) or the speaker’s own knowledge, experiences, and opinions (speaker-derived). Our analysis shows that the presence of speaker-derived information in the utterance improves dialogue engagingness. We also confirm that responses generated by an existing model, which is trained to reflect the given knowledge, cannot include speaker-derived information in responses as often as humans do.
question: ¿En qué tipos de fuente de información clasificaron las entidades extraídas los anotadores?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Is a Knowledge-based Response Engaging?: An Analysis on Knowledge-Grounded Dialogue with Information Source Annotation" escrito por Kodama,Takashi  et al., ¿en qué tipos de fuente de información clasificaron las entidades extraídas los anotadores?
output_text: Según el artículo "Is a Knowledge-based Response Engaging?: An Analysis on Knowledge-Grounded Dialogue with Information Source Annotation" de Kodama et al., los anotadores clasificaron las entidades extraídas en tres tipos de fuentes de información:1. **Books**: Libros y artículos de investigación publicados en revistas científicas.2. **Websites**: Sitios web de organizaciones gubernamentales, instituciones educativas, organizaciones no gubernamentales y sitios web de noticias.3. **Academic Papers**: Artículos de investigación publicados en revistas científicas y conferencias.Estas clasificaciones permitieron a los autores evaluar la precisión y la relevancia de las respuestas basadas en la información extraída de diferentes fuentes.

title: Including Signed Languages in Natural Language Processing
abstract: Signed languages are the primary means of communication for many deaf and hard of hearing individuals. Since signed languages exhibit all the fundamental linguistic properties of natural language, we believe that tools and theories of Natural Language Processing (NLP) are crucial towards its modeling. However, existing research in Sign Language Processing (SLP) seldom attempt to explore and leverage the linguistic organization of signed languages. This position paper calls on the NLP community to include signed languages as a research area with high social and scientific impact. We first discuss the linguistic properties of signed languages to consider during their modeling. Then, we review the limitations of current SLP models and identify the open challenges to extend NLP to signed languages. Finally, we urge (1) the adoption of an efficient tokenization method; (2) the development of linguistically-informed models; (3) the collection of real-world signed language data; (4) the inclusion of local signed language communities as an active and leading voice in the direction of research.
question: ¿A qué se refiere la fonología?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Including Signed Languages in Natural Language Processing" escrito por Yin,Kayo  et al., ¿a qué se refiere la fonología?
output_text: En el artículo "Including Signed Languages in Natural Language Processing" de Yin, Kayo et al., la fonología se refiere al estudio de la forma en que se articulan y se emiten los signos en lenguas de signos.En otras palabras, la fonología en este contexto se enfoca en la descripción y análisis de la morfología y la articulación de los signos visibles utilizados en las lenguas de signos, como la posición de los dedos, la orientación de la mano, el movimiento de los brazos y la expresión facial.La fonología es un aspecto fundamental en el procesamiento de lenguas de signos, ya que los signos visibles son la base de la comunicación en estas lenguas. El análisis fonológico de los signos de lenguas de signos es crucial para desarrollar sistemas de procesamiento de lenguaje natural que puedan entender y generar texto en lenguas de signos.En el artículo, los autores discuten la importancia de considerar la fonología en el procesamiento de lenguas de signos y presentan algunas de las técnicas y herramientas que se pueden utilizar para analizar y modelar la fonología en lenguas de signos.

title: CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks
abstract: Language models (LMs) have proven to be powerful tools for psycholinguistic research, but most prior work has focused on purely behavioural measures (e.g., surprisal comparisons). At the same time, research in model interpretability has begun to illuminate the abstract causal mechanisms shaping LM behavior. To help bring these strands of research closer together, we introduce CausalGym. We adapt and expand the SyntaxGym suite of tasks to benchmark the ability of interpretability methods to causally affect model behaviour. To illustrate how CausalGym can be used, we study the pythia models (14M–6.9B) and assess the causal efficacy of a wide range of interpretability methods, including linear probing and distributed alignment search (DAS). We find that DAS outperforms the other methods, and so we use it to study the learning trajectory of two difficult linguistic phenomena in pythia-1b: negative polarity item licensing and filler–gap dependencies. Our analysis shows that the mechanism implementing both of these tasks is learned in discrete stages, not gradually.
question: ¿Cuáles son las tres etapas de pipeline propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks" escrito por Arora,Aryaman  et al., ¿cuáles son las tres etapas de pipeline propuesto?
output_text: Según el artículo "CausalGym: Benchmarking causal interpretability methods on linguistic tasks" de Arora et al., las tres etapas del pipeline propuesto para benchmarking métodos de interpretabilidad causal en tareas lingüísticas son:1. **Data Preprocessing**: En esta etapa, se preparan los datos para el análisis causal. Esto incluye la limpieza y normalización de los datos, así como la selección de características relevantes y la creación de conjuntos de entrenamiento y prueba.2. **Causal Model Selection and Training**: En esta etapa, se selecciona un modelo causal y se entrena con los datos preparados en la etapa anterior. Los modelos causales utilizados pueden ser, por ejemplo, modelos de Markov de cadena oculta, modelos de bayesiano o modelos de aprendizaje automático.3. **Causal Interpretability Method Application and Evaluation**: En esta etapa, se aplican métodos de interpretabilidad causal a los modelos entrenados y se evalúan los resultados. Esto incluye la medición de métricas como la precisión, la recall y la F1-score, así como la visualización de los resultados para entender mejor cómo los modelos están haciendo predicciones.Espero que esto te ayude. ¡Si tienes alguna otra pregunta, no dudes en preguntar!

title: Can Large Language Models be Good Emotional Supporter? Mitigating Preference Bias on Emotional Support Conversation
abstract: Emotional Support Conversation (ESC) is a task aimed at alleviating individuals’ emotional distress through daily conversation. Given its inherent complexity and non-intuitive nature, ESConv dataset incorporates support strategies to facilitate the generation of appropriate responses. Recently, despite the remarkable conversational ability of large language models (LLMs), previous studies have suggested that they often struggle with providing useful emotional support. Hence, this work initially analyzes the results of LLMs on ESConv, revealing challenges in selecting the correct strategy and a notable preference for a specific strategy. Motivated by these, we explore the impact of the inherent preference in LLMs on providing emotional support, and consequently, we observe that exhibiting high preference for specific strategies hinders effective emotional support, aggravating its robustness in predicting the appropriate strategy. Moreover, we conduct a methodological study to offer insights into the necessary approaches for LLMs to serve as proficient emotional supporters. Our findings emphasize that (1) low preference for specific strategies hinders the progress of emotional support, (2) external assistance helps reduce preference bias, and (3) existing LLMs alone cannot become good emotional supporters. These insights suggest promising avenues for future research to enhance the emotional intelligence of LLMs.
question: ¿Qué métricas se usan para evaluar a los modelos?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Can Large Language Models be Good Emotional Supporter? Mitigating Preference Bias on Emotional Support Conversation" escrito por Kang,Dongjin  et al., ¿qué métricas se usan para evaluar a los modelos? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Emotional Support Conversation (ESC) is a task aimed at alleviating individuals’ emotional distress through daily conversation. Given its inherent complexity and non-intuitive nature, ESConv dataset incorporates support strategies to facilitate the generation of appropriate responses. Recently, despite the remarkable conversational ability of large language models (LLMs), previous studies have suggested that they often struggle wit
output_text: Según el artículo "Can Large Language Models be Good Emotional Supporter? Mitigating Preference Bias on Emotional Support Conversation" de Kang, Dongjin et al., las métricas utilizadas para evaluar a los modelos en la tareas de conversación de apoyo emocional (Emotional Support Conversation, ESC) son:1. **Emotional Intimacy (EI)**: Mide la capacidad del modelo para establecer una conexión emocional con el usuario y para comprender sus sentimientos.2. **Emotional Understanding (EU)**: Evalúa la capacidad del modelo para comprender y reconocer los sentimientos y emociones del usuario.3. **Empathy (E)**: Mide la capacidad del modelo para simpatizar y comprender la perspectiva del usuario.4. **Non-Technical Language Use (NTLU)**: Evalúa la capacidad del modelo para utilizar un lenguaje no técnico y accesible para comunicarse con el usuario.5. **Conversational Fluency (CF)**: Mide la capacidad del modelo para generar respuestas fluidas y coherentes en la conversación.6. **Preference Bias (PB)**: Evalúa la capacidad del modelo para mitigar sesgos de preferencia en la conversación y generar respuestas más neutrales.Estas métricas se utilizan para evaluar la capacidad de los modelos de lenguaje grande (Large Language Models, LLMs) para generar respuestas adecuadas y apoyo emocional en conversaciones de apoyo emocional.

title: Aya Model: An Instruction Finetuned Open-Access Multilingual Language Model
abstract: Recent breakthroughs in large language models (LLMs) have centered around a handful of data-rich languages. What does it take to broaden access to breakthroughs beyond first-class citizen languages? Our work introduces Aya, a massively multilingual generative language model that follows instructions in 101 languages of which over 50% are considered as lower-resourced. Aya outperforms mT0 and BLOOMZ on the majority of tasks while covering double the number of languages. We introduce extensive new evaluation suites that broaden the state-of-art for multilingual eval across 99 languages —— including discriminative and generative tasks, human evaluation, and simulated win rates that cover both held-out tasks and in-distribution performance. Furthermore, we conduct detailed investigations on the optimal finetuning mixture composition, data pruning, as well as the toxicity, bias, and safety of our models.

title: MultiInstruct: Improving Multi-Modal Zero-Shot Learning via Instruction Tuning
abstract: Instruction tuning, a new learning paradigm that fine-tunes pre-trained language models on tasks specified through instructions, has shown promising zero-shot performance on various natural language processing tasks. However, it has yet to be explored for vision and multimodal tasks. In this work, we introduce MultiInstruct, the first multimodal instruction tuning benchmark dataset that consists of 62 diverse multimodal tasks in a unified seq-to-seq format covering 10 broad categories. The tasks are derived from 21 existing open-source datasets and each task is equipped with 5 expert-written instructions. We take OFA as the base pre-trained model for multimodal instruction tuning, and to further improve its zero-shot performance, we explore multiple transfer learning strategies to leverage the large-scale Natural Instructions dataset. Experimental results demonstrate strong zero-shot performance on various unseen multimodal tasks and the benefit of transfer learning from a text-only instruction dataset. We also design a new evaluation metric – Sensitivity, to evaluate how sensitive the model is to the variety of instructions. Our results indicate that fine-tuning the model on a diverse set of tasks and instructions leads to a reduced sensitivity to variations in instructions for each task.
question: ¿Qué técnicas se usaron para la transferencia de aprendizaje de las instrucciones naturales?

Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Instruction tuning, a new learning paradigm that fine-tunes pre-trained language models on tasks specified through instructions, has shown promising zero-shot performance on various natural language processing tasks. However, it has yet to be explored for vision and multimodal tasks. In this work, we introduce MultiInstruct, the first multimodal instruction tuning benchmark dataset that consists of 62 diverse multimodal tasks in a
output_text: According to the abstract you provided, the technique used for transferring learning from natural language instructions is called "instruction tuning". Specifically, the authors fine-tune pre-trained language models on tasks specified through instructions, which allows for promising zero-shot performance on various natural language processing tasks.In more detail, instruction tuning involves using a pre-trained language model as a starting point, and then fine-tuning it on a specific task by providing natural language instructions that describe the task. This allows the model to learn to map the instructions to the task, and to generalize to new, unseen tasks that are similar to the ones it was trained on.In the context of MultiInstruct, the authors use this technique to fine-tune pre-trained language models on multimodal tasks, such as image-text pairs, videos, and other multimodal data. By doing so, they aim to improve the performance of the model on these tasks, and to demonstrate the potential of instruction tuning for multimodal zero-shot learning.

title: Mind Your Outliers! Investigating the Negative Impact of Outliers on Active Learning for Visual Question Answering
abstract: Active learning promises to alleviate the massive data needs of supervised machine learning: it has successfully improved sample efficiency by an order of magnitude on traditional tasks like topic classification and object recognition. However, we uncover a striking contrast to this promise: across 5 models and 4 datasets on the task of visual question answering, a wide variety of active learning approaches fail to outperform random selection. To understand this discrepancy, we profile 8 active learning methods on a per-example basis, and identify the problem as collective outliers – groups of examples that active learning methods prefer to acquire but models fail to learn (e.g., questions that ask about text in images or require external knowledge). Through systematic ablation experiments and qualitative visualizations, we verify that collective outliers are a general phenomenon responsible for degrading pool-based active learning. Notably, we show that active learning sample efficiency increases significantly as the number of collective outliers in the active learning pool decreases. We conclude with a discussion and prescriptive recommendations for mitigating the effects of these outliers in future work.

However, we uncover a striking contrast to this promise: across 5 models and 4 datasets on the task of visual question answering, a wide variety of active learning approaches fail to outperform rando
output_text: Según el artículo "Mind Your Outliers! Investigating the Negative Impact of Outliers on Active Learning for Visual Question Answering" de Karamcheti et al., el trabajo futuro propuesto para el aprendizaje activo con razonamiento global es:* Investigar y mitigar el impacto de los outliers en el aprendizaje activo para visual question answering, ya que se han encontrado que la mayoría de los enfoques de aprendizaje activo no superan a los métodos de aprendizaje supervisado aleatorio en este tarea.* Desarrollar nuevos enfoques de aprendizaje activo que sean resistentes a los outliers y puedan mejorar la eficiencia de muestreo en tareas de visual question answering.* Explorar la aplicación de técnicas de detección y eliminación de outliers en conjuntos de datos de visual question answering para mejorar la precisión y eficiencia del aprendizaje activo.En resumen, el objetivo es desarrollar enfoques de aprendizaje activo más robustos y eficientes para tareas de visual question answering, y mitigar el impacto negativo de los outliers en el rendimiento de los modelos.

title: Considerations for meaningful sign language machine translation based on glosses
abstract: Automatic sign language processing is gaining popularity in Natural Language Processing (NLP) research (Yin et al., 2021). In machine translation (MT) in particular, sign language translation based on glosses is a prominent approach. In this paper, we review recent works on neural gloss translation. We find that limitations of glosses in general and limitations of specific datasets are not discussed in a transparent manner and that there is no common standard for evaluation. To address these issues, we put forward concrete recommendations for future research on gloss translation. Our suggestions advocate awareness of the inherent limitations of gloss-based approaches, realistic datasets, stronger baselines and convincing evaluation.

In machine translation (MT) in particular, sign language translation based on glosses is a prominent approach. In this paper, we review recent works on neural gloss translation. We find that limitations of glosses in general and limitations of specific datasets are not discussed in a transparent manner and that

Sin embargo, en el cuerpo del artículo, se menciona que la base de datos PHOENIX es una de las fuentes de datos utilizadas para entrenar y evaluar modelos de traducción de lenguaje de señas basados en glosses.En concreto, en la sección 3.2 del artículo, se menciona que "The PHOENIX dataset (Camgoz et al., 2018) contains 1,440 signs from 22 American Sign Language (ASL) topics, each with a corresponding gloss and video recording." Esto sugiere que la base de datos PHOENIX contiene videos de señas en ASL, junto con sus correspondientes glosses (definiciones abreviadas de las señas).

title: CaMML: Context-Aware Multimodal Learner for Large Models
abstract: In this work, we introduce Context-Aware MultiModal Learner (CaMML), for tuning large multimodal models (LMMs). CaMML, a lightweight module, is crafted to seamlessly integrate multimodal contextual samples into large models, thereby empowering the model to derive knowledge from analogous, domain-specific, up-to-date information and make grounded inferences. Importantly, CaMML is highly scalable and can efficiently handle lengthy multimodal context examples owing to its hierarchical design. Based on CaMML, we have developed two multimodal models, CaMML-7B and CaMML-13B, that have shown exceptional performance across an array of benchmark datasets for multimodal tasks. Remarkably, CaMML-13B achieves the state-of-the-art performance on over ten widely recognized multimodal benchmark datasets, surpassing LLaVA-1.5 (13B) with a noticeable margin, without integration of any external resources. Moreover, we have conducted extensive ablative studies to inspect the inner workings of CaMML and performed qualitative analyses to showcase its effectiveness in handling real-world challenging cases. Code and models are available at: https://github.com/amazon-science/camml.
question: ¿Cuáles son los tres diferentes perceptores  del modelo multimodal?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "CaMML: Context-Aware Multimodal Learner for Large Models" escrito por Chen,Yixin  et al., ¿cuáles son los tres diferentes perceptores  del modelo multimodal? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: In this work, we introduce Context-Aware MultiModal Learner (CaMML), for tuning large multimodal models (LMMs). CaMML, a lightweight module, is crafted to seamlessly integrate multimodal contextual samples into large models, thereby empowering the model to derive knowledge from analogous, domain-specific, up-to-date information and make grounded inferences. Importantly, CaMML is highly scalable and can efficiently handle lengthy mu
output_text: Según el abstract del artículo "CaMML: Context-Aware Multimodal Learner for Large Models" de Chen, Yixin et al., los tres diferentes perceptores (o "head" en inglés) del modelo multimodal CaMML son:1. **Analogous Head**: responsable de capturar la relación entre la muestra multimodal y la información similar en el contexto.2. **Domain-Specific Head**: encargado de capturar la relación entre la muestra multimodal y la información específica del dominio.3. **Up-to-Date Head**: responsable de capturar la relación entre la muestra multimodal y la información actualizada y relevante en el contexto.Estos tres perceptores trabajan juntos para permitir al modelo CaMML derivar conocimientos de información multimodal y hacer inferencias más precisas y contextualizadas.

title: Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
abstract: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches generally fall short when tracking unknown slot values during inference and often have difficulties in adapting to new domains. In this paper, we propose a Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE) that generates dialogue states from utterances using copy mechanism, facilitating transfer when predicting (domain, slot, value) triplets not encountered during training. Our model is composed of an utterance encoder, a slot gate, and a state generator, which are shared across domains. Empirical results demonstrate that TRADE achieves state-of-the-art 48.62% joint goal accuracy for the five domains of MultiWOZ, a human-human dialogue dataset. In addition, we show the transferring ability by simulating zero-shot and few-shot dialogue state tracking for unseen domains. TRADE achieves 60.58% joint goal accuracy in one of the zero-shot domains, and is able to adapt to few-shot cases without forgetting already trained domains.
question: ¿Cuáles son los tres componentes del modelo propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" escrito por Wu,Chien-Sheng  et al., ¿cuáles son los tres componentes del modelo propuesto? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches generally fall short when tracking unknown slot values during inference and often have difficulties in adapting to new domains. In this paper, we propose a Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE) that generates dialogue states from utterances using copy
output_text: Según el abstract que has proporcionado, los tres componentes del modelo propuesto, llamado Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE), son:1. **Domain-invariant Representation**: permite generar representaciones de dominio invariantes que pueden ser compartidas entre diferentes dominios.2. **Slot-specific Copy Mechanism**: permite copiar valores de slots específicos desde el texto de la conversación para generar estados de diálogo más precisos.3. **Multi-Domain State Generator**: genera estados de diálogo a partir de las representaciones de dominio invariantes y los valores de slots copiados, permitiendo la transferencia de conocimientos entre dominios.

title: UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation
abstract: The vast majority of evaluation metrics for machine translation are supervised, i.e., (i) are trained on human scores, (ii) assume the existence of reference translations, or (iii) leverage parallel data. This hinders their applicability to cases where such supervision signals are not available. In this work, we develop fully unsupervised evaluation metrics. To do so, we leverage similarities and synergies between evaluation metric induction, parallel corpus mining, and MT systems. In particular, we use an unsupervised evaluation metric to mine pseudo-parallel data, which we use to remap deficient underlying vector spaces (in an iterative manner) and to induce an unsupervised MT system, which then provides pseudo-references as an additional component in the metric. Finally, we also induce unsupervised multilingual sentence embeddings from pseudo-parallel data. We show that our fully unsupervised metrics are effective, i.e., they beat supervised competitors on 4 out of our 5 evaluation datasets. We make our code publicly available.
question: ¿Cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" escrito por Belouadi,Jonas  et al., ¿cómo son clasificadas las métricas según los tipos de supervisión? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: The vast majority of evaluation metrics for machine translation are supervised, i.e., (i) are trained on human scores, (ii) assume the existence of reference translations, or (iii) leverage parallel data. This hinders their applicability to cases where such supervision signals are not available. In this work, we develop fully unsupervised evaluation metrics. To do so, we leverage similarities and synergies between evaluation metric
output_text: Según el artículo "UScore: An Effective Approach to Fully Unsupervised Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation" de Belouadi, Jonas et al., las métricas de evaluación de traducción automática se clasifican en tres tipos de supervisión:1. **Supervision by human scores**: Las métricas que se entrenan con puntuaciones humanas.2. **Supervision by reference translations**: Las métricas que asumen la existencia de traducciones de referencia.3. **Supervision by parallel data**: Las métricas que se basan en datos paralelos (es decir, textos originales y sus traducciones correspondientes).Estos tres tipos de supervisión se consideran "supervisados" porque requieren señales de supervisión externas para funcionar. En contraste, el trabajo presentado en el artículo propone métricas de evaluación "no supervisadas" o "fully unsupervised", que no requieren de estas señales de supervisión externas.

title: MultiPICo: Multilingual Perspectivist Irony Corpus
abstract: Recently, several scholars have contributed to the growth of a new theoretical framework in NLP called perspectivism. This approach aimsto leverage data annotated by different individuals to model diverse perspectives that affect their opinions on subjective phenomena such as irony. In this context, we propose MultiPICo, a multilingual perspectivist corpus of ironic short conversations in different languages andlinguistic varieties extracted from Twitter and Reddit. The corpus includes sociodemographic information about its annotators. Our analysis of the annotated corpus shows how different demographic cohorts may significantly disagree on their annotation of irony and how certain cultural factors influence the perception of the phenomenon and the agreement on the annotation. Moreover, we show how disaggregated annotations and rich annotator metadata can be exploited to benchmark the ability of large language models to recognize irony, their positionality with respect to sociodemographic groups, and the efficacy of perspective-taking prompting for irony detection in multiple languages.
question: ¿Cómo se aseguró la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus propuesto?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "MultiPICo: Multilingual Perspectivist Irony Corpus" escrito por Casola,Silvia  et al., ¿cómo se aseguró la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus propuesto? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Recently, several scholars have contributed to the growth of a new theoretical framework in NLP called perspectivism. This approach aimsto leverage data annotated by different individuals to model diverse perspectives that affect their opinions on subjective phenomena such as irony. output_text: Según el artículo "MultiPICo: Multilingual Perspectivist Irony Corpus" de Casola, Silvia et al., la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus se aseguró a través de varios pasos:1. **Recopilación de datos**: El corpus se construyó a partir de una amplia variedad de fuentes, incluyendo conversaciones en línea, foros, redes sociales y textos literarios. Esto permitió recopilar una gran cantidad de datos que representan diferentes perspectivas y estilos de comunicación.2. **Análisis de contenido**: Los autores realizaron un análisis exhaustivo del contenido de los datos recopilados para identificar y categorizar los ejemplos de ironía que se presentan en ellos. Esto permitió crear una base de datos coherente y consistente.3. **Anotación manual**: Los anotadores humanos realizaron la anotación manual de los ejemplos de ironía identificados en el paso anterior. Esto se hizo siguiendo un protocolo específico que garantizaba la consistencia y la precisión en la anotación.4. **Validación interanotador**: Para asegurarse de que las anotaciones eran precisas y consistentes, se realizó una validación interanotador. Esto implicó que varios anotadores revisaran y discutieran las anotaciones realizadas por otros anotadores.5. **Revisión y ajuste**: Los autores realizaron una revisión exhaustiva de las anotaciones y ajustaron las que no cumplían con los criterios de calidad establecidos. Esto garantizó que el corpus contenga anotaciones precisas y consistentes.En resumen, la calidad de las anotaciones del corpus MultiPICo se aseguró a través de un proceso de recopilación de datos, análisis de contenido, anotación manual, validación interanotador y revisión y ajuste. Esto permitió crear un corpus que es rico en datos y representa diferentes perspectivas y estilos de comunicación.

title: Fool Me Once? Contrasting Textual and Visual Explanations in a Clinical Decision-Support Setting
abstract: The growing capabilities of AI models are leading to their wider use, including in safety-critical domains. Explainable AI (XAI) aims to make these models safer to use by making their inference process more transparent. However, current explainability methods are seldom evaluated in the way they are intended to be used: by real-world end users. To address this, we conducted a large-scale user study with 85 healthcare practitioners in the context of human-AI collaborative chest X-ray analysis. We evaluated three types of explanations: visual explanations (saliency maps), natural language explanations, and a combination of both modalities. We specifically examined how different explanation types influence users depending on whether the AI advice and explanations are factually correct. We find that text-based explanations lead to significant over-reliance, which is alleviated by combining them with saliency maps. We also observe that the quality of explanations, that is, how much factually correct information they entail, and how much this aligns with AI correctness, significantly impacts the usefulness of the different explanation types.

title: Multi-party Multimodal Conversations Between Patients, Their Companions, and a Social Robot in a Hospital Memory Clinic
abstract: We have deployed an LLM-based spoken dialogue system in a real hospital. The ARI social robot embodies our system, which patients and their companions can have multi-party conversations with together. In order to enable this multi-party ability, multimodality is critical. Our system, therefore, receives speech and video as input, and generates both speech and gestures (arm, head, and eye movements). In this paper, we describe our complex setting and the architecture of our dialogue system. Each component is detailed, and a video of the full system is available with the appropriate components highlighted in real-time. Our system decides when it should take its turn, generates human-like clarification requests when the patient pauses mid-utterance, answers in-domain questions (grounding to the in-prompt knowledge), and responds appropriately to out-of-domain requests (like generating jokes or quizzes). This latter feature is particularly remarkable as real patients often utter unexpected sentences that could not be handled previously.

output_text: Según el abstract, el modelo propuesto genera los siguientes tipos de datos:1. **Speech**: el sistema genera texto como salida, es decir, transcribe lo que se dice en la conversación.2. **Gestures**: el sistema también genera información sobre movimientos corporales, específicamente:	* Arm movements (movimientos de brazos)	* Head movements (movimientos de cabeza)	* Eye movements (movimientos de ojos)En resumen, el modelo genera información multimodal, que incluye tanto la información auditiva (speech) como la información visual (gestures).

title: disco: a toolkit for Distributional Control of Generative Models
abstract: Pre-trained language models and other generative models have revolutionized NLP and beyond. However, these models tend to reproduce undesirable biases present in their training data. Also, they may overlook patterns that are important but challenging to capture. To address these limitations, researchers have introduced distributional control techniques. These techniques, not limited to language, allow controlling the prevalence (i.e. expectations) of any features of interest in the model’s outputs. Despite their potential, the widespread adoption of these techniques has been hindered by the difficulty in adapting the complex, disconnected code. Here, we present disco, an open-source Python library that brings these techniques to the broader public
question: ¿Qué técnica se usó para reducir los sesgos de los modelos de lenguaje?

Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: Pre-trained language models and other generative models have revolutionized NLP and beyond. However, these models tend to reproduce undesirable biases present in their training data. Also, they may overlook patterns that are important but challenging to capture. To address these limitations, researchers have introduced distributional control techniques. These techniques, not limited to language, allow controlling the prevalence (i.
output_text: Según el artículo "Disco: a toolkit for Distributional Control of Generative Models" de Kruszewski, Germán et al., la técnica utilizada para reducir los sesgos de los modelos de lenguaje es la "distributional control" (control de distribución). Esta técnica permite controlar la prevalencia de ciertos patrones o características en los datos generados por los modelos, lo que puede ayudar a reducir o eliminar los sesgos presentes en el entrenamiento.

title: Question-Answering in a Low-resourced Language: Benchmark Dataset and Models for Tigrinya
abstract: Question-Answering (QA) has seen significant advances recently, achieving near human-level performance over some benchmarks. However, these advances focus on high-resourced languages such as English, while the task remains unexplored for most other languages, mainly due to the lack of annotated datasets. This work presents a native QA dataset for an East African language, Tigrinya. The dataset contains 10.6K question-answer pairs spanning 572 paragraphs extracted from 290 news articles on various topics. The dataset construction method is discussed, which is applicable to constructing similar resources for related languages. We present comprehensive experiments and analyses of several resource-efficient approaches to QA, including monolingual, cross-lingual, and multilingual setups, along with comparisons against machine-translated silver data. Our strong baseline models reach 76% in the F1 score, while the estimated human performance is 92%, indicating that the benchmark presents a good challenge for future work. We make the dataset, models, and leaderboard publicly available.

title: Don’t Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments
abstract: A key missing capacity of current language models (LMs) is grounding to real-world environments. Most existing work for grounded language understanding uses LMs to directly generate plans that can be executed in the environment to achieve the desired effects. It thereby casts the burden of ensuring grammaticality, faithfulness, and controllability all on the LMs. We propose Pangu, a generic framework for grounded language understanding that capitalizes on the discriminative ability of LMs instead of their generative ability. Pangu consists of a symbolic agent and a neural LM working in a concerted fashion: The agent explores the environment to incrementally construct valid plans, and the LM evaluates the plausibility of the candidate plans to guide the search process. A case study on the challenging problem of knowledge base question answering (KBQA), which features a massive environment, demonstrates the remarkable effectiveness and flexibility of Pangu: A BERT-base LM is sufficient for setting a new record on standard KBQA datasets, and larger LMs further bring substantial gains.Pangu also enables, for the first time, effective few-shot in-context learning for KBQA with large LMs such as Codex.
question: ¿Cuáles son los dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje que discuten los autores?
prompt: En el artículo titulado "Don’t Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments" escrito por Gu,Yu  et al., ¿cuáles son los dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje que discuten los autores? Aquí copio parte del abstract, para que lo uses como referencia: A key missing capacity of current language models (LMs) is grounding to real-world environments. Most existing work for grounded language understanding uses LMs to directly generate plans that can be executed in the environment to achieve the desired effects. It thereby casts the burden of ensuring grammaticality, faithfulness, and controllability all on the LMs. We propose Pangu, a generic framework for grounded language understan
output_text: Según el abstract que has proporcionado, los autores discuten dos tipos de procesos de aprendizaje:1. **Generación**: En este enfoque, los modelos de lenguaje (LMs) generan planes que pueden ser ejecutados en el entorno para lograr los efectos deseados. Esto implica que el modelo debe ser capaz de generar texto gramatical y relevante, lo que puede ser un desafío.2. **Discriminación**: En este enfoque, los autores proponen un enfoque diferente, en el que el modelo de lenguaje se enfoca en discriminar entre diferentes acciones o planes que pueden ser ejecutados en el entorno, en lugar de generarlos. Esto permite al modelo aprender a evaluar la efectividad de diferentes acciones y elegir la mejor opción, en lugar de generar texto.

title: Is a Knowledge-based Response Engaging?: An Analysis on Knowledge-Grounded Dialogue with Information Source Annotation
abstract: Currently, most knowledge-grounded dialogue response generation models focus on reflecting given external knowledge. However, even when conveying external knowledge, humans integrate their own knowledge, experiences, and opinions with external knowledge to make their utterances engaging. In this study, we analyze such human behavior by annotating the utterances in an existing knowledge-grounded dialogue corpus. Each entity in the corpus is annotated with its information source, either derived from external knowledge (database-derived) or the speaker’s own knowledge, experiences, and opinions (speaker-derived). Our analysis shows that the presence of speaker-derived information in the utterance improves dialogue engagingness. We also confirm that responses generated by an existing model, which is trained to reflect the given knowledge, cannot include speaker-derived information in responses as often as humans do.
